verses.textEn: The parables of Solomon, son of David, king of Israel,
verses.textLa: Parabolæ Salomonis, filii David, regis Israel.

verses.textEn: in order to know wisdom and discipline,
verses.textLa: Ad sciendam sapientiam, et disciplinam:

verses.textEn: to understand words of prudence, and to accept the instruction of doctrine, justice and judgment, and equity,
verses.textLa: ad intelligenda verba prudentiæ: et suscipiendam eruditionem doctrinæ, iustitiam, et iudicium, et æquitatem:

verses.textEn: so as to give discernment to little ones, knowledge and understanding to adolescents.
verses.textLa: ut detur parvulis astutia, adolescenti scientia, et intellectus.

verses.textEn: By listening, the wise shall become wiser and the intelligent shall possess governments.
verses.textLa: Audiens, sapiens sapientior erit: et intelligens gubernacula possidebit.
verses.notes: The word ‘gubernacula’ could also more generally refer to ‘positions of leadership.’ Note how sapiens and intelligens are used as nouns, but audiens is used as a participle; this is discerned from the context.

verses.textEn: He shall turn his soul to a parable and to its interpretation, to the words of the wise and their enigmas.
verses.textLa: Animadvertet parabolam, et interpretationem, verba sapientum, et ænigmata eorum.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom. The foolish despise wisdom as well as doctrine.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini principium sapientiæ. Sapientiam, atque doctrinam stulti despiciunt.
verses.notes: The word ‘foolish’ is a better translation than ‘fools’ because ‘foolish’ describes a person by their behavior, which may change.

verses.textEn: Listen, my son, to the discipline of your father, and forsake not the law of your mother,
verses.textLa: Audi, fili mi, disciplinam patris tui, et ne dimittas legem matris tuæ:

verses.textEn: so that grace may be added to your head and a collar to your neck.
verses.textLa: ut addatur gratia capiti tuo, et torques collo tuo.
verses.notes: A ‘torques’ can refer to a necklace of twisted metal, but it can also refer to non-metal adornment around the neck. In this translation, using a Christological and specifically Roman Catholic meaning, the text is taken as referring to the collar of a priest.

verses.textEn: My son, if sinners should entice you, do not consent to them.
verses.textLa: Fili mi, si te lactaverint peccatores, ne acquiescas eis.

verses.textEn: If they should say: “Come with us. We will lie in wait for blood. We will lay traps against the innocent, without cause.
verses.textLa: Si dixerint: Veni nobiscum, insidiemur sanguini, abscondamus tendiculas contra insontem frustra:

verses.textEn: Let us swallow him alive, like Hell, and whole, like one descending into the pit.
verses.textLa: deglutiamus eum sicut infernus viventem, et integrum quasi descendentem in lacum.

verses.textEn: We will discover every precious substance. We will fill our houses with spoils.
verses.textLa: Omnem pretiosam substantiam reperiemus, implebimus domos nostras spoliis.

verses.textEn: Cast your lot with us. One purse will be for us all.”
verses.textLa: Sortem mitte nobiscum, marsupium unum sit omnium nostrum.

verses.textEn: My son, do not walk with them. Preclude your feet from their paths.
verses.textLa: Fili mi, ne ambules cum eis, prohibe pedem tuum a semitis eorum.
verses.notes: Why are these parables addressed to ‘my son,’ i.e. to a man, or to men in general? First, it is Solomon speaking to David, which in essence is itself a parable of a wise father speaking to his son. Second, in a special way, God is using this book to speak to priests. Third, it foreshadows the wisdom of the Son of God, Jesus Christ. Fourth, we are all (men, women, and children) called to be like the Son of God. And there may be other reasons.

verses.textEn: For their feet rush to evil, and they hurry to shed blood.
verses.textLa: Pedes enim illorum ad malum currunt, et festinant ut effundant sanguinem.

verses.textEn: But a net is thrown in vain before the eyes of those who have wings.
verses.textLa: Frustra autem iacitur rete ante oculos pennatorum.

verses.textEn: Likewise, they lie in ambush against their own blood, and they undertake deceits against their own souls.
verses.textLa: Ipsi quoque contra sanguinem suum insidiantur, et moliuntur fraudes contra animas suas.

verses.textEn: Thus, the ways of all those who are greedy seize the souls of those who possess.
verses.textLa: Sic semitæ omnis avari, animas possidentium rapiunt.

verses.textEn: Wisdom forewarns far and wide; she bestows her voice in the streets.
verses.textLa: Sapientia foris prædicat, in plateis dat vocem suam:

verses.textEn: She cries out at the head of crowds; at the entrance of the gates of the city, she offers her words, saying:
verses.textLa: in capite turbarum clamitat, in foribus portarum urbis profert verba sua, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Little ones, how long will you choose to be childish, and how long will the foolish desire what is harmful to themselves, and how long will the imprudent hate knowledge?
verses.textLa: Usquequo parvuli diligitis infantiam, et stulti ea, quæ sibi sunt noxia, cupient, et imprudentes odibunt scientiam?

verses.textEn: Be converted by my correction. Lo, I will offer my spirit to you, and I will reveal my words to you.
verses.textLa: Convertimini ad correptionem meam: en proferam vobis spiritum meum, et ostendam vobis verba mea.

verses.textEn: For I called, and you refused. I extended my hand, and there was no one who watched.
verses.textLa: Quia vocavi, et renuistis: extendi manum meam, et non fuit qui aspiceret.

verses.textEn: You have despised all my counsels, and you have neglected my rebukes.
verses.textLa: Despexistis omne consilium meum, et increpationes meas neglexistis.

verses.textEn: Similarly, I will ridicule you at your demise, and I will mock you, when that which you feared shall overcome you.
verses.textLa: Ego quoque in interitu vestro ridebo, et subsannabo, cum vobis id, quod timebatis, advenerit.

verses.textEn: When sudden calamity rushes upon you, and your demise advances like a tempest, when tribulation and anguish overcome you,
verses.textLa: Cum irruerit repentina calamitas, et interitus quasi tempestas ingruerit: quando venerit super vos tribulatio, et angustia:

verses.textEn: then they will call to me, and I will not heed, they will arise in the morning, and not find me.
verses.textLa: Tunc invocabunt me, et non exaudiam: mane consurgent, et non invenient me:

verses.textEn: For they held hatred for discipline, and they would not accept the fear of the Lord;
verses.textLa: eo quod exosam habuerint disciplinam, et timorem Domini non susceperint,

verses.textEn: they would not consent to my counsel, but they detracted from all of my corrections.
verses.textLa: nec acquieverint consilio meo, et detraxerint universæ correptioni meæ.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they shall eat the fruit of their way, and they shall have their fill of their own counsels.
verses.textLa: Comedent igitur fructus viæ suæ, suisque consiliis saturabuntur.

verses.textEn: The loathing of the little ones shall destroy them, and the prosperity of the foolish shall perish them.
verses.textLa: Aversio parvulorum interficiet eos, et prosperitas stultorum perdet illos.

verses.textEn: But whoever will listen to me shall rest without terror, and shall have full enjoyment of abundance, without fear of evils.”
verses.textLa: Qui autem me audierit, absque terrore requiescet, et abundantia perfruetur, timore malorum sublato.

verses.textEn: My son, if you would accept my words, and conceal my commandments within you,
verses.textLa: Fili mi, si susceperis sermones meos, et mandata mea absconderis penes te,

verses.textEn: so that your ears may listen to wisdom, then bend your heart in order to know prudence.
verses.textLa: ut audiat sapientiam auris tua: inclina cor tuum ad cognoscendam prudentiam.

verses.textEn: For if you would call upon wisdom and bend your heart to prudence,
verses.textLa: Si enim sapientiam invocaveris, et inclinaveris cor tuum prudentiæ:

verses.textEn: if you will seek her like money, and dig for her as if for treasure,
verses.textLa: si quæsieris eam quasi pecuniam, et sicut thesauros effoderis illam:

verses.textEn: then you will understand the fear of the Lord, and you will discover the knowledge of God.
verses.textLa: tunc intelliges timorem Domini, et scientiam Dei invenies:

verses.textEn: For the Lord bestows wisdom, and out of his mouth, prudence and knowledge.
verses.textLa: quia Dominus dat sapientiam: et ex ore eius prudentia, et scientia.

verses.textEn: He will preserve the salvation of the righteous, and he will protect those who walk in simplicity:
verses.textLa: Custodiet rectorum salutem, et proteget gradientes simpliciter,

verses.textEn: serving the paths of justice, and guarding the ways of sanctity.
verses.textLa: servans semitas iustitiæ, et vias sanctorum custodiens.

verses.textEn: Then you shall understand justice and judgment, and equity, and every good path.
verses.textLa: Tunc intelliges iustitiam, et iudicium, et æquitatem, et omnem semitam bonam.

verses.textEn: If wisdom is to enter into your heart, and if knowledge is to become pleasing to your soul,
verses.textLa: Si intraverit sapientia cor tuum, et scientia animæ tuæ placuerit:

verses.textEn: then counsel must guard you, and prudence must serve you,
verses.textLa: consilium custodiet te, et prudentia servabit te,

verses.textEn: so that you may be rescued from the evil way, and from the man who speaks perversities,
verses.textLa: ut eruaris a via mala, et ab homine, qui perversa loquitur:

verses.textEn: from those who leave the straight path to walk in dark ways,
verses.textLa: qui relinquunt iter rectum, et ambulant per vias tenebrosas:

verses.textEn: who rejoice when they have done evil, and who exult in the most wicked things.
verses.textLa: qui lætantur cum malefecerint, et exultant in rebus pessimis:

verses.textEn: Their ways are perverse, and their steps are infamous.
verses.textLa: quorum viæ perversæ sunt, et infames gressus eorum.

verses.textEn: So may you be rescued from the foreign woman, and from the outsider, who softens her speech,
verses.textLa: Ut eruaris a muliere aliena, et ab extranea, quæ mollit sermones suos,
verses.notes: The word ‘extranea’ is feminine here, but in English the feminine is discerned from the subsequent use of ‘her’.

verses.textEn: and who leaves behind the Guide of her youth,
verses.textLa: et relinquit Ducem pubertatis suæ,

verses.textEn: and who has forgotten the covenant of her God. For her household inclines toward death, and her paths toward Hell.
verses.textLa: et pacti Dei sui oblita est. Inclinata est enim ad mortem domus eius, et ad inferos semitæ ipsius.

verses.textEn: All those who enter to her will not return again, nor will they take hold of the paths of life.
verses.textLa: Omnes, qui ingrediuntur ad eam, non revertentur, nec apprehendent semitas vitæ.

verses.textEn: So may you walk in the good way, and keep to the difficult paths of the just.
verses.textLa: Ut ambules in via bona: et calles iustorum custodias.
verses.notes: The word ‘calles’ is difficult to render in English in just one word. It refers to a less traveled, uneven or difficult path, such as a mountain path, or a rocky or narrow path.

verses.textEn: For those who are upright shall live upon the earth, and the simple shall continue upon it.
verses.textLa: Qui enim recti sunt, habitabunt in terra, et simplices permanebunt in ea.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, the impious shall perish from the earth, and those who act unjustly shall be taken away from it.
verses.textLa: Impii vero de terra perdentur: et qui inique agunt, auferentur ex ea.

verses.textEn: My son, do not forget my law, but let your heart guard my precepts.
verses.textLa: Fili mi, ne obliviscaris legis meæ, et præcepta mea cor tuum custodiat.

verses.textEn: For they shall set before you length of days, and years of life, and peace.
verses.textLa: Longitudinem enim dierum, et annos vitæ, et pacem apponent tibi.

verses.textEn: Let not mercy and truth abandon you: encircle them around your throat, and inscribe them on the tablets of your heart.
verses.textLa: Misericordia, et veritas te non deserant, circumda eas gutturi tuo, et describe in tabulis cordis tui:

verses.textEn: And so shall you discover grace and good discipline, in the sight of God and men.
verses.textLa: et invenies gratiam, et disciplinam bonam coram Deo et hominibus.

verses.textEn: Have confidence in the Lord with all your heart, and do not depend upon your own prudence.
verses.textLa: Habe fiduciam in Domino ex toto corde tuo, et ne innitaris prudentiæ tuæ.

verses.textEn: In all your ways, consider him, and he himself will direct your steps.
verses.textLa: In omnibus viis tuis cogita illum, et ipse diriget gressus tuos.

verses.textEn: Do not seem wise to yourself. Fear God, and withdraw from evil.
verses.textLa: Ne sis sapiens apud temetipsum: time Deum, et recede a malo:

verses.textEn: Certainly, it shall be health to your navel, and refreshment to your bones.
verses.textLa: sanitas quippe erit umbilico tuo, et irrigatio ossium tuorum.

verses.textEn: Honor the Lord with your substance, and give to him from the first of all your fruits,
verses.textLa: Honora Dominum de tua substantia, et de primitiis omnium frugum tuarum da ei:

verses.textEn: and then your storehouses will be filled with abundance, and your presses shall overflow with wine.
verses.textLa: et implebuntur horrea tua saturitate, et vino torcularia tua redundabunt.

verses.textEn: My son, do not discard the discipline of the Lord, and do not fall away when you are corrected by him.
verses.textLa: Disciplinam Domini, fili mi, ne abiicias: nec deficias cum ab eo corriperis:

verses.textEn: For whomever the Lord loves, he corrects, and just as a father does with a son, he wins him over.
verses.textLa: quem enim diligit Dominus, corripit: et quasi pater in filio complacet sibi.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man who finds wisdom and who advances to prudence.
verses.textLa: Beatus homo, qui invenit sapientiam, et qui affluit prudentia:

verses.textEn: Her acquisition is better than trading in silver, and her fruit is better than the first and purest gold.
verses.textLa: melior est acquisitio eius negotiatione argenti, et auri primi et purissimi fructus eius:

verses.textEn: She is more precious than all riches, and all that can be desired cannot prevail in comparison to her.
verses.textLa: pretiosior est cunctis opibus: et omnia, quæ desiderantur, huic non valent comparari.

verses.textEn: Length of days is at her right hand, and at her left hand is wealth and glory.
verses.textLa: Longitudo dierum in dextera eius, et in sinistra illius divitiæ, et gloria.

verses.textEn: Her ways are beautiful ways, and all her paths are peaceful.
verses.textLa: Viæ eius viæ pulchræ, et omnes semitæ illius pacificæ.

verses.textEn: She is a tree of life to those who overtake her, and he who shall take hold of her is blessed.
verses.textLa: Lignum vitæ est his, qui apprehenderint eam: et qui tenuerit eam, beatus.

verses.textEn: The Lord founded the earth on wisdom. He secured the heavens with prudence.
verses.textLa: Dominus sapientia fundavit terram, stabilivit cælos prudentia.

verses.textEn: By his wisdom, the abyss erupted and the clouds increased with dew.
verses.textLa: Sapientia illius eruperunt abyssi, et nubes rore concrescunt.

verses.textEn: My son, let not these things move away from your eyes. Preserve law as well as counsel.
verses.textLa: Fili mi, ne effluant hæc ab oculis tuis: Custodi legem atque consilium:

verses.textEn: And so shall there be life in your soul and grace in your voice.
verses.textLa: et erit vita animæ tuæ, et gratia faucibus tuis.

verses.textEn: Then you shall walk confidently in your way, and your feet will not stumble.
verses.textLa: Tunc ambulabis fiducialiter in via tua, et pes tuus non impinget:

verses.textEn: When you slumber, you shall not fear. When you rest, your sleep also will be sweet.
verses.textLa: si dormieris, non timebis: quiesces, et suavis erit somnus tuus.

verses.textEn: Do not fear unexpected terror, nor the power of the impious falling upon you.
verses.textLa: Ne paveas repentino terrore, et irruentes tibi potentias impiorum.

verses.textEn: For the Lord will be at your side, and he will guard your feet, so that you may not be seized.
verses.textLa: Dominus enim erit in latere tuo, et custodiet pedem tuum ne capiaris.

verses.textEn: Do not prevent him who is able from doing good. When you are able, do good yourself too.
verses.textLa: Noli prohibere benefacere eum, qui potest: si vales, et ipse benefac:

verses.textEn: Do not say to your friend: “Go away, and then return. Tomorrow I will give to you.” When you are able to do so, give in the present.
verses.textLa: Ne dicas amico tuo: Vade, et revertere: cras dabo tibi: cum statim possis dare.

verses.textEn: Do not undertake evil against your friend, even though he has trust in you.
verses.textLa: Ne moliaris amico tuo malum, cum ille in te habeat fiduciam.

verses.textEn: Do not contend against a man without cause, even though he has done no evil to you.
verses.textLa: Ne contendas adversus hominem frustra, cum ipse tibi nihil mali fecerit.

verses.textEn: Do not rival an unjust man, and do not imitate his ways.
verses.textLa: Ne æmuleris hominem iniustum, nec imiteris vias eius:
verses.notes: Or, ‘Do not compete with an unjust man,’ or, ‘Do not rival an unjust man.’

verses.textEn: For everyone who ridicules is an abomination to the Lord, and his communication is for the simple.
verses.textLa: quia abominatio Domini est omnis illusor, et cum simplicibus sermocinatio eius.

verses.textEn: Destitution in the house of the impious is from the Lord. But the habitations of the just shall be blessed.
verses.textLa: Egestas a Domino in domo impii: habitacula autem iustorum benedicentur.

verses.textEn: He will ridicule those who ridicule, but he will bestow grace upon the mild.
verses.textLa: Ipse deludet illusores, et mansuetis dabit gratiam.

verses.textEn: The wise will possess glory. The exaltation of the foolish is disgraceful.
verses.textLa: Gloriam sapientes possidebunt: stultorum exaltatio, ignominia.

verses.textEn: Listen, sons, to the discipline of a father, and pay attention, so that you may know prudence.
verses.textLa: Audite filii disciplinam patris, et attendite ut sciatis prudentiam.

verses.textEn: I will bestow upon you a good gift. Do not relinquish my law.
verses.textLa: Donum bonum tribuam vobis, legem meam ne derelinquatis.

verses.textEn: For I, too, was the son of my father, tender and an only son in the sight of my mother.
verses.textLa: Nam et ego filius fui patris mei, tenellus, et unigenitus coram matre mea:

verses.textEn: And he taught me, and he also said: “Let your heart accept my words. Keep my precepts, and you shall live.
verses.textLa: et docebat me, atque dicebat: Suscipiat verba mea cor tuum, custodi præcepta mea, et vives.

verses.textEn: Obtain wisdom, obtain prudence. May you neither forget, nor turn away from, the words of my mouth.
verses.textLa: Posside sapientiam, posside prudentiam: ne obliviscaris, neque declines a verbis oris mei.

verses.textEn: Do not send her away, and she will guard you. Love her, and she will preserve you.
verses.textLa: Ne dimittas eam, et custodiet te: dilige eam, et conservabit te.

verses.textEn: The beginning of wisdom is to obtain wisdom, and, with all that you possess, to acquire prudence.
verses.textLa: Principium sapientiæ, posside sapientiam, et in omni possessione tua acquire prudentiam.

verses.textEn: Grasp her, and she will exalt you. You will be glorified by her, when you have embraced her.
verses.textLa: Arripe illam, et exaltabit te: glorificaberis ab ea, cum eam fueris amplexatus.

verses.textEn: She will bestow upon your head an increase in graces, and she will protect you with a noble crown.
verses.textLa: Dabit capiti tuo augmenta gratiarum, et corona inclyta proteget te.

verses.textEn: Listen, my son, and accept my words, so that years of life may be multiplied for you.
verses.textLa: Audi fili mi, et suscipe verba mea, ut multiplicentur tibi anni vitæ.

verses.textEn: I will demonstrate to you the way of wisdom. I will lead you along the paths of equity.
verses.textLa: Viam sapientiæ monstrabo tibi, ducam te per semitas æquitatis:

verses.textEn: When you have entered by these, your steps will not be constrained, and when running, you will have no obstacle.
verses.textLa: quas cum ingressus fueris, non arctabuntur gressus tui, et currens non habebis offendiculum.

verses.textEn: Take hold of discipline. Do not dismiss it. Guard it, for it is your life.
verses.textLa: Tene disciplinam, ne dimittas eam: custodi illam, quia ipsa est vita tua.

verses.textEn: Do not delight in the paths of the impious, nor permit the way of evil-doers to please you.
verses.textLa: Ne delecteris in semitis impiorum, nec tibi placeat malorum via.

verses.textEn: Take flight from it. Do not pass close to it. Turn away and abandon it.
verses.textLa: Fuge ab ea, nec transeas per illam: declina, et desere eam.

verses.textEn: For they do not sleep, unless they have done evil. And their sleep is quickly taken away from them, unless they have overthrown.
verses.textLa: Non enim dormiunt nisi malefecerint: et rapitur somnus ab eis nisi supplantaverint.

verses.textEn: They eat the bread of impiety, and they drink the wine of iniquity.
verses.textLa: Comedunt panem impietatis, et vinum iniquitatis bibunt.

verses.textEn: But the path of the just is like a shining light: it advances and increases, even to the day of completion.
verses.textLa: Iustorum autem semita quasi lux splendens, procedit et crescit usque ad perfectam diem.

verses.textEn: The way of the impious is darkened. They do not know where they may fall.
verses.textLa: Via impiorum tenebrosa: nesciunt ubi corruant.

verses.textEn: My son, pay attention to my sermons, and incline your ear to my eloquent words.
verses.textLa: Fili mi, ausculta sermones meos, et ad eloquia mea inclina aurem tuam.

verses.textEn: Let them not recede from your eyes. Keep them in the midst of your heart.
verses.textLa: Ne recedant ab oculis tuis, custodi ea in medio cordis tui:

verses.textEn: For they are life to those who find them and health to all that is flesh.
verses.textLa: vita enim sunt invenientibus ea, et universæ carni sanitas.

verses.textEn: Preserve your heart with all watchfulness, for life proceeds from this.
verses.textLa: Omni custodia serva cor tuum, quia ex ipso vita procedit.

verses.textEn: Remove from yourself a corrupt mouth, and let detracting lips be far from you.
verses.textLa: Remove a te os pravum, et detrahentia labia sint procul a te.

verses.textEn: Let your eyes look straight ahead, and let your eyelids precede your steps.
verses.textLa: Oculi tui recta videant, et palpebræ tuæ præcedant gressus tuos.

verses.textEn: Direct the path of your feet, and all your ways shall be secure.
verses.textLa: Dirige semitam pedibus tuis, et omnes viæ tuæ stabilientur.

verses.textEn: Turn aside, neither to the right, nor to the left; yet turn your foot away from evil. For the Lord knows the ways that are on the right, and truly, those that are on the left are perverse. But he himself will make your courses straight. Then your journey will advance in peace.
verses.textLa: Ne declines ad dexteram, neque ad sinistram: averte pedem tuum a malo. Vias enim, quæ a dextris sunt, novit Dominus: perversæ vero sunt quæ a sinistris sunt. Ipse autem rectos faciet cursus tuos, itinera autem tua in pace producet.

verses.textEn: My son, pay attention to my wisdom, and incline your ear to my prudence,
verses.textLa: Fili mi, attende ad sapientiam meam, et prudentiæ meæ inclina aurem tuam,

verses.textEn: so that you may guard your thinking, and so that your lips may preserve discipline. Do not pay attention to the deceit of a woman.
verses.textLa: ut custodias cogitationes, et disciplinam labia tua conservent. Ne attendas fallaciæ mulieris.

verses.textEn: For the lips of a loose woman are like a dripping honeycomb, and her voice is smoother than oil.
verses.textLa: Favus enim distillans labia meretricis, et nitidius oleo guttur eius.
verses.notes: The word ‘meretricis’ can mean prostitute, but it can also, more often, refer to a woman who behaves like a prostitute: either a kept woman with only one lover, or a promiscuous woman with many lovers. The translation as ‘loose woman’ is a better fit for the meaning of the text. As is clear from the previous verse, this passage is not merely warning against prostitution, but against loose living.

verses.textEn: But in the end, she is as bitter as wormwood, and as sharp as a two-edged sword.
verses.textLa: Novissima autem illius amara quasi absinthium, et acuta quasi gladius biceps.

verses.textEn: Her feet descend into death, and her steps reach even to Hell.
verses.textLa: Pedes eius descendunt in mortem, et ad inferos gressus illius penetrant.

verses.textEn: They do not walk along the path of life; her steps are wandering and untraceable.
verses.textLa: Per semitam vitæ non ambulant, vagi sunt gressus eius, et investigabiles.

verses.textEn: Therefore, my son, listen to me now, and do not withdraw from the words of my mouth.
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo fili mi audi me, et ne recedas a verbis oris mei.

verses.textEn: Make your way at a distance from her, and do not approach the doors of her house.
verses.textLa: Longe fac ab ea viam tuam, et ne appropinques foribus domus eius.

verses.textEn: Do not give your honor to foreigners, and your years to the cruel.
verses.textLa: Ne des alienis honorem tuum, et annos tuos crudeli.

verses.textEn: Otherwise, outsiders may be filled with your strength, and your labors may be in a foreign house,
verses.textLa: Ne forte implentur extranei viribus tuis, et labores tui sint in domo aliena,

verses.textEn: and you may mourn in the end, when you will have consumed your flesh and your body. And so you may say:
verses.textLa: et gemas in novissimis, quando consumseris carnes tuas et corpus tuum, et dicas:

verses.textEn: “Why have I detested discipline, and why has my heart not been quieted by correction?
verses.textLa: Cur detestatus sum disciplinam, et increpationibus non acquievit cor meum,

verses.textEn: And why have I not listened to the voice of those who guided me? And why has my ear not inclined to my teachers?
verses.textLa: nec audivi vocem docentium me, et magistris non inclinavi aurem meam?

verses.textEn: I have almost been with all evil in the midst of the church and of the assembly.”
verses.textLa: Pene fui in omni malo, in medio ecclesiæ et synagogæ.

verses.textEn: Drink water from your own cistern and from the springs of your own well.
verses.textLa: Bibe aquam de cisterna tua, et fluenta putei tui:

verses.textEn: Let your fountains be diverted far and wide, and divide your waters in the streets.
verses.textLa: Deriventur fontes tui foras, et in plateis aquas tuas divide.
verses.notes:
This verse seems to contradict the previous and subsequent verses. The original Douay-Rheims version has a note that relates water to doctrine. My understanding of that note: distribute good doctrine far and wide among men of sincere intention, but not to those who make themselves to be foreigners to the truth.
 The previous verse (5:15) refers to drinking water from ones own well. This can refer to doctrine, as verses 12 to 14 indicate. This can also refer to chastity and marriage, as the subsequent verses indicate. However, verse 5:16 cannot be taken to refer to sexuality, but only to doctrine. It often happens, as Scripture weaves together comments on a variety of related subjects, that some verses are to be understood more narrowly, and others more broadly.

verses.textEn: Hold them for yourself alone, and do not let strangers be partakers with you.
verses.textLa: Habeto eas solus, nec sint alieni participes tui.
verses.notes:
When applied to doctrine, this verse and the previous one can be understood in a number of ways. Concerning doctrine, one can distribute it far and wide, sharing it in the streets. Or one can keep it to oneself, so that only you and God know your thoughts about the Faith. But in either case, one cannot ‘let strangers be partakers’ casting the pearls of true doctrine before those swine who ridicule and despise the truth.
 It is not so unusual to have two consecutive verses that seem to contradict one another. This technique of writing causes the reader to think about the correct meaning of each verse. This is also seen later in Proverbs when the topic is responding to the foolish according to their folly.

verses.textEn: Let your spring be blessed, and rejoice with the wife of your youth:
verses.textLa: Sit vena tua benedicta, et lætare cum muliere adolescentiæ tuæ:
verses.notes: So then, rejoice in true doctrine with your beloved wife. Share the Faith with her. But also, this verse refers in a figurative manner to marital relations.

verses.textEn: a beloved doe and most pleasing fawn. Let her breasts inebriate you at all times. Be delighted continually by her love.
verses.textLa: cerva charissima, et gratissimus hinnulus. Ubera eius inebrient te in omni tempore, in amore eius delectare iugiter.

verses.textEn: Why are you seduced, my son, by a strange woman, and why are you kept warm by the bosom of another?
verses.textLa: Quare seduceris fili mi ab aliena, et foveris in sinu alterius?

verses.textEn: The Lord beholds the ways of man, and he considers all his steps.
verses.textLa: Respicit Dominus vias hominis, et omnes gressus eius considerat.

verses.textEn: His own iniquities take hold of the impious, and he is bound by the cords of his own sins.
verses.textLa: Iniquitates suas capiunt impium, et funibus peccatorum suorum constringitur.

verses.textEn: He shall die, for he has not held to discipline. And by the multitude of his foolishness, he shall be deceived.
verses.textLa: Ipse morietur, quia non habuit disciplinam, et in multitudine stultitiæ suæ decipietur.

verses.textEn: My son, if you have taken a pledge on behalf of your friend, then you have bound your hand to an outsider,
verses.textLa: Fili mi, si spoponderis pro amico tuo, defixisti apud extraneum manum tuam,

verses.textEn: then you are ensnared by the words of your own mouth, and taken captive by your own words.
verses.textLa: illaqueatus es verbis oris tui, et captus propriis sermonibus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, my son, do what I say, and free yourself, for you have fallen into the hand of your neighbor. Run, hurry, awaken your friend.
verses.textLa: Fac ergo quod dico fili mi, et temetipsum libera: quia incidisti in manum proximi tui. Discurre, festina, suscita amicum tuum:

verses.textEn: Do not grant sleep to your eyes, nor let your eyelids slumber.
verses.textLa: ne dederis somnum oculis tuis, nec dormitent palpebræ tuæ.

verses.textEn: Rescue yourself like a gazelle from the hand, and like a bird from the hand of the fowler.
verses.textLa: Eruere quasi damula de manu, et quasi avis de manu aucupis.

verses.textEn: Go to the ant, you lazy one, and consider her ways, and so learn wisdom.
verses.textLa: Vade ad formicam o piger, et considera vias eius, et disce sapientiam:

verses.textEn: For though she has no ruler, nor instructor, nor leader,
verses.textLa: quæ cum non habeat ducem, nec præceptorem, nec principem,

verses.textEn: she provides meals for herself in the summer, and she gathers at the harvest what she may eat.
verses.textLa: parat in æstate cibum sibi, et congregat in messe quod comedat.

verses.textEn: How long will you slumber, you lazy one? When will you rise up from your sleep?
verses.textLa: Usquequo piger dormies? quando consurges e somno tuo?

verses.textEn: You will sleep a little, you will slumber a little, you will fold your hands a little to sleep,
verses.textLa: Paululum dormies, paululum dormitabis, paululum conseres manus ut dormias:

verses.textEn: and then destitution will meet with you, like a traveler, and poverty, like an armed man. Yet truly, if you would be diligent, then your harvest will arrive like a fountain, and destitution will flee far from you.
verses.textLa: et veniet tibi quasi viator, egestas, et pauperies quasi vir armatus. Si vero impiger fueris, veniet ut fons messis tua, et egestas longe fugiet a te.

verses.textEn: An apostate man, a harmful man, walks with a perverse mouth;
verses.textLa: Homo apostata, vir inutilis, graditur ore perverso,
verses.notes: One meaning of this passage is to refer to the Antichrist. The word ‘inutilis’ can mean ‘useless,’ but in the context of apostasy and perverse words, it must have its alternate meaning, which is ‘harmful.’

verses.textEn: he winks with the eyes, touches with the foot, speaks with the finger.
verses.textLa: annuit oculis, terit pede, digito loquitur,

verses.textEn: With a depraved heart he devises evil, and at all times he sows conflict.
verses.textLa: pravo corde machinatur malum, et omni tempore iurgia seminat.

verses.textEn: To this one, his perdition will arrive promptly, and he shall be crushed suddenly: he will no longer have any remedy.
verses.textLa: Huic extemplo veniet perditio sua, et subito conteretur, nec habebit ultra medicinam.

verses.textEn: Six things there are that the Lord hates, and the seventh, his soul detests:
verses.textLa: Sex sunt, quæ odit Dominus, et septimum detestatur anima eius:
verses.notes: Again, this refers, in one level of meaning to the Antichrist. He will have a reign of six years, plus part of a seventh year. The six things are the six full years of his reign, and the seventh is the most detestable time of his reign (when he attempts to make a false ascension to the heavens). The number 616 refers to the Antichrist’s name: six letters in his first name, six letters in this last name, with his middle initial in-between.

verses.textEn: haughty eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood,
verses.textLa: Oculos sublimes, linguam mendacem, manus effundentes innoxium sanguinem,

verses.textEn: a heart that devises the most wicked thoughts, feet running swiftly unto evil,
verses.textLa: cor machinans cogitationes pessimas, pedes veloces ad currendum in malum,

verses.textEn: a deceitful witness bringing forth lies, and he who sows discord among brothers.
verses.textLa: proferentem mendacia testem fallacem, et eum, qui seminat inter fratres discordias.
verses.notes: These three verses (6:17-19) are a description of the Antichrist: he tries to sow discord among the brethren of the Church; he bears false witness against the true Christ.

verses.textEn: My son, preserve the precepts of your father, and do not dismiss the law of your mother.
verses.textLa: Conserva fili mi præcepta patris tui, et ne dimittas legem matris tuæ.

verses.textEn: Bind them to your heart unceasingly, and encircle them around your throat.
verses.textLa: Liga ea in corde tuo iugiter, et circumda gutturi tuo.

verses.textEn: When you walk, let them keep step with you. When you sleep, let them guard you. And when you keep watch, speak with them.
verses.textLa: Cum ambulaveris, gradiantur tecum: cum dormieris, custodiant te, et evigilans loquere cum eis.

verses.textEn: For commandment is a lamp, and law is a light, and the reproofs of discipline are the way of life.
verses.textLa: Quia mandatum lucerna est, et lex lux, et via vitæ increpatio disciplinæ:

verses.textEn: So may they guard you from an evil woman, and from the flattering tongue of the outsider.
verses.textLa: ut custodiant te a muliere mala, et a blanda lingua extraneæ.
verses.notes: The negative things that are said in the Book of Proverbs about an evil woman or a loose (or kept) woman, can also be applied to the false prophet, who is a associated with the Antichrist and who will be a female antipope.

verses.textEn: Let not your heart desire her beauty; do not be captivated by her winks.
verses.textLa: Non concupiscat pulchritudinem eius cor tuum, nec capiaris nutibus illius:

verses.textEn: For the price of a prostitute is only one loaf. Yet the woman seizes the precious soul of a man.
verses.textLa: pretium enim scorti vix est unius panis: mulier autem viri pretiosam animam capit.
verses.notes: The loaf is the false Eucharist promoted by this female false prophet, especially when she becomes antipope. She tries to seize men’s souls with flattery. She is attractive looking, and claims to be chaste, but she a loose woman, worse than a prostitute.

verses.textEn: Would a man be able to conceal fire in his bosom, so that his garments would not burn?
verses.textLa: Numquid potest homo abscondere ignem in sinu suo, ut vestimenta illius non ardeant?

verses.textEn: Or could he walk over burning coals, so that his feet would not be burned?
verses.textLa: aut ambulare super prunas, ut non comburantur plantæ eius?

verses.textEn: So also, he who enters to the wife of his neighbor shall not be clean when he touches her.
verses.textLa: sic qui ingreditur ad mulierem proximi sui, non erit mundus cum tetigerit eam.

verses.textEn: Not so great is the fault when someone has stolen. For he steals so as to satisfy a hungry soul.
verses.textLa: Non grandis est culpa, cum quis furatus fuerit: furatur enim ut esurientem impleat animam:

verses.textEn: Also, if he is apprehended, he shall repay sevenfold and hand over all the substance of his house.
verses.textLa: deprehensus quoque reddet septuplum, et omnem substantiam domus suæ tradet.

verses.textEn: But whoever is an adulterer, because of the emptiness of his heart, will destroy his own soul.
verses.textLa: Qui autem adulter est, propter cordis inopiam perdet animam suam:

verses.textEn: He gathers shame and dishonor to himself, and his disgrace will not be wiped away.
verses.textLa: turpitudinem et ignominiam congregat sibi, et opprobrium illius non delebitur.

verses.textEn: For the jealousy and fury of the husband will not spare him on the day of vindication,
verses.textLa: Quia zelus et furor viri non parcet in die vindictæ,

verses.textEn: nor will he agree to the pleadings of anyone, nor will he accept, as repayment, a multitude of gifts.
verses.textLa: nec acquiescet cuiusquam precibus, nec suscipiet pro redemptione dona plurima.

verses.textEn: My son, guard my words and conceal my precepts within you.
verses.textLa: Fili mi, custodi sermones meos, et præcepta mea reconde tibi.

verses.textEn: Son, preserve my commandments, and you shall live. And keep my law as the pupil of your eye.
verses.textLa: Fili, serva mandata mea, et vives: et legem meam quasi pupillam oculi tui:

verses.textEn: Bind it with your fingers; write it on the tablets of your heart.
verses.textLa: liga eam in digitis tuis, scribe illam in tabulis cordis tui.

verses.textEn: Say to wisdom, “You are my sister,” and call prudence your friend.
verses.textLa: Dic sapientiæ, soror mea es: et prudentiam voca amicam tuam,

verses.textEn: So may she guard you from the woman who is an outsider, and from the stranger who sweetens her words.
verses.textLa: ut custodiant te a muliere extranea, et ab aliena, quæ verba sua dulcia facit.

verses.textEn: For I gaze from the window of my house, through the lattice,
verses.textLa: De fenestra enim domus meæ per cancellos prospexi,

verses.textEn: and I see little ones. I consider a frenzied youth,
verses.textLa: et video parvulos: considero vecordem iuvenem,

verses.textEn: who crosses the street at the corner and close to the way of that house.
verses.textLa: qui transit per plateam iuxta angulum, et prope viam domus illius, graditur

verses.textEn: He steps into shadows, as day becomes evening, into the darkness and gloom of the night.
verses.textLa: in obscuro, advesperascente die, in noctis tenebris, et caligine.

verses.textEn: And behold, a woman meets him, dressed like a harlot, prepared to captivate souls: chattering and rambling,
verses.textLa: Et ecce occurrit illi mulier ornatu meretricio, præparata ad capiendas animas: garrula, et vaga,

verses.textEn: unwilling to bear silence, unable to keep her feet at home,
verses.textLa: quietis impatiens, nec valens in domo consistere pedibus suis,

verses.textEn: now outside, now in the streets, now lying in ambush near the corners.
verses.textLa: nunc foris, nunc in plateis, nunc iuxta angulos insidians.

verses.textEn: And overtaking the youth, she kisses him, and with a provocative face, she flatters him, saying:
verses.textLa: Apprehensumque deosculatur iuvenem, et procaci vultu blanditur, dicens:

verses.textEn: “I vowed sacrifices for well-being. Today I have repaid my vows.
verses.textLa: Victimas pro salute vovi, hodie reddidi vota mea.

verses.textEn: Because of this, I have gone out to meet you, desiring to see you, and I have found you.
verses.textLa: Idcirco egressa sum in occursum tuum, desiderans te videre, et reperi.

verses.textEn: I have woven my bed with cords. I have strewn it with embroidered tapestries from Egypt.
verses.textLa: Intexui funibus lectulum meum, stravi tapetibus pictis ex Ægypto.

verses.textEn: I have sprinkled my bed with myrrh, aloe, and cinnamon.
verses.textLa: Aspersi cubile meum myrrha, et aloe, et cinnamomo.

verses.textEn: Come, let us be inebriated in abundance, and let us delight in the embraces of desire, until the day begins to dawn.
verses.textLa: Veni, inebriemur uberibus, et fruamur cupitis amplexibus, donec illucescat dies.

verses.textEn: For my husband is not in his house. He has gone away on a very long journey.
verses.textLa: Non est enim vir in domo sua, abiit via longissima.

verses.textEn: He took with him a bag of money. He will return to his house on the day of the full moon.”
verses.textLa: Sacculum pecuniæ secum tulit: in die plenæ lunæ reversurus est in domum suam.

verses.textEn: She enmeshed him with many words, and she drew him forward with the flattery of her lips.
verses.textLa: Irretivit eum multis sermonibus, et blanditiis labiorum protraxit illum.

verses.textEn: Immediately, he follows her, like an ox being led to the sacrifice, and like a lamb acting lasciviously, and not knowing that he is being drawn foolishly into chains,
verses.textLa: Statim eam sequitur quasi bos ductus ad victimam, et quasi agnus lasciviens, et ignorans quod ad vincula stultus trahatur,

verses.textEn: until the arrow pierces his liver. It is just as if a bird were to hurry into the snare. And he does not know that his actions endanger his own soul.
verses.textLa: donec transfigat sagitta iecur eius: velut si avis festinet ad laqueum, et nescit quod de periculo animæ illius agitur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, my son, hear me now, and attend to the words of my mouth.
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo fili mi, audi me, et attende verbis oris mei.

verses.textEn: Do not let your mind be pulled into her ways. And do not be deceived by her paths.
verses.textLa: Ne abstrahatur in viis illius mens tua: neque decipiaris semitis eius.

verses.textEn: For she has tossed aside many wounded, and some of those who were very strong have been slain by her.
verses.textLa: Multos enim vulneratos deiecit, et fortissimi quique interfecti sunt ab ea.

verses.textEn: Her household is the way to Hell, reaching even to the inner places of death.
verses.textLa: Viæ inferi domus eius, penetrantes in interiora mortis.

verses.textEn: Does not wisdom call out, and prudence bestow her voice?
verses.textLa: Numquid non sapientia clamitat, et prudentia dat vocem suam?

verses.textEn: At the summits and the tops of exalted places, standing above the ways, in the midst of the paths,
verses.textLa: In summis, excelsisque verticibus supra viam, in mediis semitis stans,

verses.textEn: beside the gates of the city, at the very doors, she speaks, saying:
verses.textLa: iuxta portas civitatis in ipsis foribus loquitur, dicens:

verses.textEn: “O men, to you I call out, and my voice is to the sons of men.
verses.textLa: O viri, ad vos clamito, et vox mea ad filios hominum.

verses.textEn: O little ones, understand discernment. And you who are unwise, turn your souls.
verses.textLa: Intelligite parvuli astutiam, et insipientes animadvertite.

verses.textEn: Listen, for I will speak about great things, and my lips will be opened, so as to foretell what is right.
verses.textLa: Audite, quoniam de rebus magnis locutura sum: et aperientur labia mea, ut recta prædicent.

verses.textEn: My throat shall practice truth, and my lips shall detest the impious.
verses.textLa: Veritatem meditabitur guttur meum, et labia mea detestabuntur impium.

verses.textEn: All my words are just. There is no depravity in them, and no perversity.
verses.textLa: Iusti sunt omnes sermones mei, non est in eis pravum quid, neque perversum.

verses.textEn: They are upright to those who understand, and equitable to those who discover knowledge.
verses.textLa: Recti sunt intelligentibus, et æqui invenientibus scientiam.

verses.textEn: Accept my discipline, and not money. Choose the doctrine that is greater than gold.
verses.textLa: Accipite disciplinam meam, et non pecuniam: doctrinam magis, quam aurum eligite.

verses.textEn: For wisdom is better than all that is most precious, and everything that is desirable cannot compare to her.
verses.textLa: Melior est enim sapientia cunctis pretiosissimis: et omne desiderabile ei non potest comparari.

verses.textEn: I, wisdom, dwell in counsel, and I am inside learned thoughts.
verses.textLa: Ego sapientia habito in consilio, et eruditis intersum cogitationibus.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord hates evil. I detest arrogance, and pride, and every wicked way, and a mouth with a double tongue.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini odit malum: arrogantiam, et superbiam, et viam pravam, et os bilingue detestor.

verses.textEn: Counsel is mine, and equity. Prudence is mine. Strength is mine.
verses.textLa: Meum est consilium, et æquitas, mea est prudentia, mea est fortitudo.

verses.textEn: Through me, kings reign and legislators decree just conditions.
verses.textLa: Per me reges regnant, et legum conditores iusta decernunt:

verses.textEn: Through me, princes rule and the powerful decree justice.
verses.textLa: Per me principes imperant, et potentes decernunt iustitiam.

verses.textEn: I love those who love me. And those who stand watch for me until morning shall discover me.
verses.textLa: Ego diligentes me diligo: et qui mane vigilant ad me, invenient me.

verses.textEn: With me, are wealth and glory, superb riches and justice.
verses.textLa: Mecum sunt divitiæ, et gloria, opes superbæ, et iustitia.

verses.textEn: For my fruit is better than gold and precious stones, and my progeny better than choice silver.
verses.textLa: Melior est enim fructus meus auro, et lapide pretioso, et genimina me argento electo.

verses.textEn: I walk in the way of justice, in the midst of the paths of judgment,
verses.textLa: In viis iustitiæ ambulo, in medio semitarum iudicii,

verses.textEn: so that I may enrich those who love me, and thus complete their treasures.
verses.textLa: ut ditem diligentes me, et thesauros eorum repleam.

verses.textEn: The Lord possessed me in the beginning of his ways, before he made anything, from the beginning.
verses.textLa: Dominus possedit me in initio viarum suarum, antequam quidquam faceret a principio.

verses.textEn: I was ordained from eternity, and out of antiquity, before the earth was formed.
verses.textLa: Ab æterno ordinata sum, et ex antiquis antequam terra fieret.

verses.textEn: The abyss did not yet exist, and I was already conceived; neither had the fountains of waters yet erupted.
verses.textLa: Nondum erant abyssi, et ego iam concepta eram: necdum fontes aquarum eruperant:

verses.textEn: The mountains, with their great mass, had not yet been established. Before the hills, I was brought forth.
verses.textLa: necdum montes gravi mole constiterant: ante colles ego parturiebar:

verses.textEn: Still he had not made the earth, and the rivers, and the poles of the globe of the earth.
verses.textLa: adhuc terram non fecerat, et flumina, et cardines orbis terræ.

verses.textEn: I was already present: when he prepared the heavens; when, with a certain law and a circuit, he fortified the abyss;
verses.textLa: Quando præparabat cælos, aderam: quando certa lege, et gyro vallabat abyssos:

verses.textEn: when he made firm the sky above, and set free the fountains of waters;
verses.textLa: quando æthera firmabat sursum, et librabat fontes aquarum:

verses.textEn: when he encompassed the sea within its limits, and laid down a law for the waters, lest they transgress their limits; when he weighed the foundations of the earth.
verses.textLa: quando circumdabat mari terminum suum, et legem ponebat aquis, ne transirent fines suos: quando appendebat fundamenta terræ:

verses.textEn: I was with him in composing all things. And I was delighted, throughout every day, by playing in his sight at all times,
verses.textLa: Cum eo eram cuncta componens: et delectabar per singulos dies, ludens coram eo omni tempore;

verses.textEn: playing in globe of the earth. And my delight was to be with the sons of men.
verses.textLa: ludens in orbe terrarum: et deliciæ meæ esse, cum filiis hominum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, sons, hear me now. Blessed are those who preserve my ways.
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo filii audite me: Beati, qui custodiunt vias meas.

verses.textEn: Listen to discipline, and become wise, and do not be willing to cast it aside.
verses.textLa: Audite disciplinam, et estote sapientes, et nolite abiicere eam.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man who listens to me, and who stands watch at my gates every day, and who observes at the posts of my doors.
verses.textLa: Beatus homo qui audit me, et qui vigilat ad fores meas quotidie, et observat ad postes ostii mei.

verses.textEn: He who finds me, finds life, and he will draw salvation from the Lord.
verses.textLa: Qui me invenerit, inveniet vitam, et hauriet salutem a Domino:
verses.notes: Or health, or prosperity from the Lord.

verses.textEn: But he who sins against me will wound his own soul. All who hate me love death.”
verses.textLa: qui autem in me peccaverit, lædet animam suam. Omnes, qui me oderunt, diligunt mortem.

verses.textEn: Wisdom has built a house for herself. She has hewn seven columns.
verses.textLa: Sapientia ædificavit sibi domum, excidit columnas septem.

verses.textEn: She has immolated her victims. She has mixed her wine and set forth her table.
verses.textLa: Immolavit victimas suas, miscuit vinum, et proposuit mensam suam.
verses.notes: Wine was mixed with water for drinking in ancient times. This purified the water and prevented those who drank from becoming too inebriated. The mixing of wine with water also has symbolic meaning.

verses.textEn: She has sent her maids to call out to the tower and to the fortified walls of the city,
verses.textLa: Misit ancillas suas ut vocarent ad arcem, et ad mœnia civitatis:

verses.textEn: “If anyone is little, let him come to me.” And to the unwise, she has said:
verses.textLa: Si quis est parvulus, veniat ad me. Et insipientibus locuta est:

verses.textEn: “Approach. Eat my bread, and drink the wine that I have mixed for you.
verses.textLa: Venite, comedite panem meum, et bibite vinum quod miscui vobis.

verses.textEn: Leave behind childishness. And live and walk by the ways of prudence.”
verses.textLa: Relinquite infantiam, et vivite, et ambulate per vias prudentiæ.

verses.textEn: Whoever teaches a mocker causes injury to himself. And whoever argues with the impious produces a blemish on himself.
verses.textLa: Qui erudit derisorem, ipse iniuriam sibi facit: et qui arguit impium, sibi maculam generat.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to argue with a mocker, lest he hate you. Dispute with the wise, and he will love you.
verses.textLa: Noli arguere derisorem, ne oderit te. Argue sapientem, et diliget te.

verses.textEn: Present an opportunity to the wise, and wisdom shall be added to him. Teach the just, and he will hurry to receive it.
verses.textLa: Da sapienti occasionem, et addetur ei sapientia. Doce iustum, et festinabit accipere.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and knowledge of holiness is prudence.
verses.textLa: Principium sapientiæ timor Domini: et scientia sanctorum, prudentia.

verses.textEn: For by me, your days will be multiplied and years of life will be added to you.
verses.textLa: Per me enim multiplicabuntur dies tui, et addentur tibi anni vitæ.

verses.textEn: If you would be wise, you will be so for yourself. But if you would be one who ridicules, you alone shall carry the evil.
verses.textLa: Si sapiens fueris, tibimetipsi eris: si autem illusor, solus portabis malum.

verses.textEn: A foolish and loud woman, who is full of enticements and who knows nothing at all,
verses.textLa: Mulier stulta et clamosa, plenaque illecebris, et nihil omnino sciens,

verses.textEn: sat at the entrance of her house on a seat, in a high place of the city,
verses.textLa: sedit in foribus domus suæ super sellam in excelso urbis loco,

verses.textEn: so as to call to those who were passing by the way and continuing on their journey:
verses.textLa: ut vocaret transeuntes per viam, et pergentes itinere suo:

verses.textEn: “Whoever is little, let him turn aside to me.” And to the frenzied, she said,
verses.textLa: Qui est parvulus, declinet ad me. Et vecordi locuta est:
verses.notes: Notice that the foolish woman imitates wisdom personified (both represented as feminine). They both call out to whoever is little, but the call from the foolish woman is false.

verses.textEn: “Stolen waters are more soothing, and secret bread is more pleasant.”
verses.textLa: Aquæ furtivæ dulciores sunt, et panis absconditus suavior.

verses.textEn: And he did not know that giants are there, and that her companions are in the depths of Hell.
verses.textLa: Et ignoravit quod ibi sint gigantes, et in profundis inferni convivæ eius.

verses.textEn: A wise son gladdens the father. Yet truly, a foolish son is the grief of his mother.
verses.textLa: Filius sapiens lætificat patrem: filius vero stultus mœstitia est matris suæ.

verses.textEn: Treasures of impiety will profit nothing. Truly, justice shall liberate from death.
verses.textLa: Nil proderunt thesauri impietatis: iustitia vero liberabit a morte.

verses.textEn: The Lord will not afflict with famine the soul of the just, and he will overthrow the treacheries of the impious.
verses.textLa: Non affliget Dominus fame animam iusti, et insidias impiorum subvertet.

verses.textEn: The neglectful hand has wrought destitution. But the hand of the steadfast prepares riches. He who advances by lies, this one feeds on the wind. For he is the same as one who runs after flying birds.
verses.textLa: Egestatem operata est manus remissa: manus autem fortium divitias parat. Qui nititur mendaciis, hic pascit ventos: idem autem ipse sequitur aves volantes.

verses.textEn: He who gathers the harvest is a wise son. But he who snores in warm weather is a son of confusion.
verses.textLa: Qui congregat in messe, filius sapiens est: qui autem stertit æstate, filius confusionis.
verses.notes: The word ‘æstate’ should not be understood as ‘summer,’ because harvest and other task related to planting occur in warm weather, but not necessarily in summer.

verses.textEn: The blessing of the Lord is on the head of the just. But iniquity covers the mouth of the impious.
verses.textLa: Benedictio Domini super caput iusti: os autem impiorum operit iniquitas.

verses.textEn: The remembrance of the just is with praises. And the name of the impious shall decay.
verses.textLa: Memoria iusti cum laudibus: et nomen impiorum putrescet.

verses.textEn: The wise of heart accept precepts. The foolish are cut down by the lips.
verses.textLa: Sapiens corde præcepta suscipit: stultus cæditur labiis.

verses.textEn: He who walks in simplicity walks in confidence. But he who corrupts his ways shall be discovered.
verses.textLa: Qui ambulat simpliciter, ambulat confidenter: qui autem depravat vias suas, manifestus erit.

verses.textEn: He who winks with the eye gives sorrow. And the foolish in lips shall be beaten.
verses.textLa: Qui annuit oculo, dabit dolorem: et stultus labiis verberabitur.

verses.textEn: The mouth of the just is a vein of life. And the mouth of the impious covers iniquity.
verses.textLa: Vena vitæ, os iusti: et os impiorum operit iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: Hatred rises up from disputes. And charity covers all offenses.
verses.textLa: Odium suscitat rixas: et universa delicta operit charitas.

verses.textEn: In the lips of the wise, wisdom is discovered. And a rod is for the back of one who lacks heart.
verses.textLa: In labiis sapientis invenitur sapientia: et virga in dorso eius qui indiget corde.

verses.textEn: The wise store away knowledge. But the mouth of the foolish is a neighbor to confusion.
verses.textLa: Sapientes abscondunt scientiam: os autem stulti confusioni proximum est.

verses.textEn: The substance of the rich is the city of his strength. The fear of the poor is their destitution.
verses.textLa: Substantia divitis, urbs fortitudinis eius: pavor pauperum, egestas eorum.

verses.textEn: The work of the just is unto life. But the fruit of the impious is unto sin.
verses.textLa: Opus iusti ad vitam: fructus autem impii ad peccatum.

verses.textEn: The way of life is for those who observe discipline. But whoever abandons correction wanders astray.
verses.textLa: Via vitæ, custodienti disciplinam: qui autem increpationes relinquit, errat.

verses.textEn: Lying lips conceal hatred; whoever brings forth contempt is unwise.
verses.textLa: Abscondunt odium labia mendacia: qui profert contumeliam, insipiens est.

verses.textEn: In a multitude of speaking, sin will not be lacking. But whoever tempers his lips is most prudent.
verses.textLa: In multiloquio non deerit peccatum: qui autem moderatur labia sua prudentissimus est.

verses.textEn: The tongue of the just is choice silver. But the heart of the impious is exchanged for nothing.
verses.textLa: Argentum electum, lingua iusti: cor autem impiorum pro nihilo.

verses.textEn: The lips of the just instruct many. But those who are unlearned shall die in destitution of heart.
verses.textLa: Labia iusti erudiunt plurimos: qui autem indocti sunt, in cordis egestate morientur.

verses.textEn: The blessing of the Lord causes riches. Affliction will not be a companion to them.
verses.textLa: Benedictio Domini divites facit, nec sociabitur eis afflictio.

verses.textEn: The foolish work wickedness as if in jest. But wisdom is prudence to a man.
verses.textLa: Quasi per risum stultus operatur scelus: sapientia autem est viro prudentia.
verses.notes: The term ‘viro’ is used to refer, not merely to any man, but to a man who is either virtuous or good or strong. So wisdom is prudence to a good man.

verses.textEn: What the impious fear will overwhelm them. The just shall be given their desire.
verses.textLa: Quod timet impius, veniet super eum: desiderium suum iustus dabitur.

verses.textEn: Like a passing tempest, so the impious one will be no more. But the just one is like an everlasting foundation.
verses.textLa: Quasi tempestas transiens non erit impius: iustus autem quasi fundamentum sempiternum.

verses.textEn: Like vinegar to the teeth, and smoke to the eyes, so is a lazy one to those who sent him.
verses.textLa: Sicut acetum dentibus, et fumus oculis, sic piger his, qui miserunt eum.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord adds days. And the years of the impious will be shortened.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini apponet dies: et anni impiorum breviabuntur.

verses.textEn: The expectation of the just is rejoicing. But the hope of the impious will perish.
verses.textLa: Expectatio iustorum lætitia: spes autem impiorum peribit.

verses.textEn: The strength of the simple is the way of the Lord, and it is fear to those who work evil.
verses.textLa: Fortitudo simplicis via Domini: et pavor his, qui operantur malum.

verses.textEn: The just in eternity shall not be moved. But the impious will not live upon the earth.
verses.textLa: Iustus in æternum non commovebitur: impii autem non habitabunt super terram.

verses.textEn: The mouth of the just shall bring forth wisdom. The tongue of the depraved will perish.
verses.textLa: Os iusti parturiet sapientiam: lingua pravorum peribit.

verses.textEn: The lips of the just consider what is acceptable. And the mouth of the impious considers perversities.
verses.textLa: Labia iusti considerant placita: et os impiorum perversa.

verses.textEn: A deceitful scale is an abomination with the Lord, and a fair weighing is his will.
verses.textLa: Statera dolosa, abominatio est apud Dominum: et pondus æquum, voluntas eius.

verses.textEn: Wherever arrogance may be, there too is insult. But wherever humility is, there too is wisdom.
verses.textLa: Ubi fuerit superbia, ibi erit et contumelia: ubi autem est humilitas, ibi et sapientia.

verses.textEn: The simplicity of the just shall direct them, and the rebellion of the perverse will devastate them.
verses.textLa: Simplicitas iustorum diriget eos: et supplantatio perversorum vastabit illos.

verses.textEn: Wealth will not profit in the day of vengeance. But justice shall liberate from death.
verses.textLa: Non proderunt divitiæ in die ultionis: iustitia autem liberabit a morte.

verses.textEn: The justice of the simple shall direct his way. And the impious will fall in his impiety.
verses.textLa: Iustitia simplicis diriget viam eius: et in impietate sua corruet impius.
verses.notes: The Challoner version adds ‘prosperous’ after his way. This is an indication that Challoner was perhaps working from a slightly different version of the Clementine Vulgate than the Vercellone and Hetzenauer editions used in the CPDV.

verses.textEn: The justice of the upright shall free them. And the iniquitous will be seized by their own treachery.
verses.textLa: Iustitia rectorum liberabit eos: et in insidiis suis capientur iniqui.

verses.textEn: When the impious man is dead, there will no longer be any hope. And the expectation of the anxious will perish.
verses.textLa: Mortuo homine impio, nulla erit ultra spes: et expectatio solicitorum peribit.

verses.textEn: The just one is freed from anguish. And the impious one will be handed over instead of him.
verses.textLa: Iustus de angustia liberatus est: et tradetur impius pro eo.

verses.textEn: The pretender deceives his friend by mouth. But the just shall be freed by knowledge.
verses.textLa: Simulator ore decipit amicum suum: iusti autem liberabuntur scientia.

verses.textEn: In the good of the just, the city shall exult. And in the perdition of the impious, there shall be praise.
verses.textLa: In bonis iustorum exultabit civitas: et in perditione impiorum erit laudatio.
verses.notes: Or, ‘there shall be a eulogy.’

verses.textEn: By the blessing of the just, the city shall be exalted. And by the mouth of the impious, it will be subverted.
verses.textLa: Benedictione iustorum exaltabitur civitas: et ore impiorum subvertetur.

verses.textEn: Whoever despises his friend is destitute in heart. But the prudent man will remain silent.
verses.textLa: Qui despicit amicum suum, indigens corde est: vir autem prudens tacebit.

verses.textEn: Whoever walks dishonestly reveals secrets. But whoever is of a faithful soul conceals what is confided by a friend.
verses.textLa: Qui ambulat fraudulenter, revelat arcana: qui autem fidelis est animi, celat amici commissum.

verses.textEn: Where there is no governor, the people shall fall. But where there is much counsel, well-being shall be.
verses.textLa: Ubi non est gubernator, populus corruet: salus autem, ubi multa consilia.

verses.textEn: He will be afflicted with evil, who provides a guarantee for an outsider. But whoever is wary of traps shall be secure.
verses.textLa: Affligetur malo, qui fidem facit pro extraneo: qui autem cavet laqueos, securus erit.

verses.textEn: A gracious woman shall discover glory. And the robust will have wealth.
verses.textLa: Mulier gratiosa inveniet gloriam: et robusti habebunt divitias.

verses.textEn: A merciful man benefits his own soul. But whoever is cruel casts out even his close relatives.
verses.textLa: Benefacit animæ suæ vir misericors: qui autem crudelis est, etiam propinquos abiicit.

verses.textEn: The impious does work with inconstancy. But for the sower of justice, there is the reward of faithfulness.
verses.textLa: Impius facit opus instabile: seminanti autem iustitiam merces fidelis.

verses.textEn: Clemency prepares life. And the pursuit of evils prepares death.
verses.textLa: Clementia præparat vitam: et sectatio malorum mortem.

verses.textEn: A depraved heart is abominable to the Lord. And his will is with those who walk in simplicity.
verses.textLa: Abominabile Domino cor pravum: et voluntas eius in iis, qui simpliciter ambulant.

verses.textEn: Hand in hand, the evil shall not be innocent. But the offspring of the just shall be saved.
verses.textLa: Manus in manu non erit innocens malus: semen autem iustorum salvabitur.

verses.textEn: A beautiful and senseless woman is like a gold ring in the snout of a swine.
verses.textLa: Circulus aureus in naribus suis, mulier pulchra et fatua.

verses.textEn: The desire of the just is entirely good. The anticipation of the impious is fury.
verses.textLa: Desiderium iustorum omne bonum est: præstolatio impiorum furor.

verses.textEn: Some distribute their own goods, and they become wealthier. Others seize what is not their own, and they are always in need.
verses.textLa: Alii dividunt propria, et ditiores fiunt: alii rapiunt non sua, et semper in egestate sunt.

verses.textEn: The soul that blesses shall be made fat. And whoever inebriates will likewise be inebriated himself.
verses.textLa: Anima, quæ benedicit, impinguabitur: et qui inebriat, ipse quoque inebriabitur.

verses.textEn: Whoever hides away grain shall be cursed among the people. But a blessing is upon the head of those who sell it.
verses.textLa: Qui abscondit frumenta, maledicetur in populis: benedictio autem super caput vendentium.

verses.textEn: He does well to rise early, who seeks what is good. But whoever is a seeker of evils shall be oppressed by them.
verses.textLa: Bene consurgit diluculo qui quærit bona: qui autem investigator malorum est, opprimetur ab eis.

verses.textEn: Whoever trusts in his riches will fall. But the just shall spring up like a green leaf.
verses.textLa: Qui confidit in divitiis suis, corruet: iusti autem quasi virens folium germinabunt.

verses.textEn: Whoever troubles his own house will possess the winds. And whoever is foolish will serve the wise.
verses.textLa: Qui conturbat domum suam, possidebit ventos: et qui stultus est, serviet sapienti.

verses.textEn: The fruit of the just one is the tree of life. And whoever receives souls is wise.
verses.textLa: Fructus iusti lignum vitæ: et qui suscipit animas, sapiens est.

verses.textEn: If the just are repaid upon the earth, how much more the impious and the sinner!
verses.textLa: Si iustus in terra recipit, quanto magis impius et peccator!

verses.textEn: Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge. But whoever hates correction is unwise.
verses.textLa: Qui diligit disciplinam, diligit scientiam: qui autem odit increpationes, insipiens est.

verses.textEn: Whoever is good shall draw grace from the Lord. But whoever trusts in his own thoughts acts impiously.
verses.textLa: Qui bonus est, hauriet gratiam a Domino: qui autem confidit in cogitationibus suis, impie agit.

verses.textEn: Man will not be made strong from impiety. And the root of the just shall not be moved.
verses.textLa: Non roborabitur homo ex impietate: et radix iustorum non commovebitur.

verses.textEn: A diligent woman is a crown to her husband. And she who acts with confusion as to which things are worthy is decay to his bones.
verses.textLa: Mulier diligens, corona est viro suo: et putredo in ossibus eius, quæ confusione res dignas gerit.

verses.textEn: The thoughts of the just are judgments. And the counsels of the impious are dishonest.
verses.textLa: Cogitationes iustorum iudicia: et consilia impiorum fraudulenta:

verses.textEn: The words of the impious lie in wait for blood. The mouth of the just shall free them.
verses.textLa: Verba impiorum insidiantur sanguini: os iustorum liberabit eos.

verses.textEn: Turn from the impious, and they will not be. But the house of the just shall stand firm.
verses.textLa: Verte impios, et non erunt: domus autem iustorum permanebit.

verses.textEn: A man will be known by his doctrine. But whoever is vain and heartless will suffer contempt.
verses.textLa: Doctrina sua noscetur vir: qui autem vanus et excors est, patebit contemptui.
verses.notes: Now I know that ‘excors’ often is translated as ‘silly’ or ‘stupid,’ but the root of the word ‘excordis’ is ‘cordis’, which means ‘of the heart.’ And the word ‘heart’ can often refer to understanding and compassion, not merely to feelings. So, ‘excors’ translated as ‘heartless’ conveys the meaning of the verse better than ‘silly’ or ‘stupid.’

verses.textEn: Better is a pauper who has what he needs, than someone glorious and in need of bread.
verses.textLa: Melior est pauper et sufficiens sibi, quam gloriosus et indigens pane.

verses.textEn: The just one knows the lives of his beasts. But the inner most parts of the impious are cruel.
verses.textLa: Novit iustus iumentorum suorum animas: viscera autem impiorum crudelia.
verses.notes: Or, ‘but the impious are cruel to their inner most parts.’

verses.textEn: Whoever works his land shall be satisfied with bread. But whoever continually pursues leisure is most foolish. Whoever is soothed by lingering over wine leaves behind contempt in his strongholds.
verses.textLa: Qui operatur terram suam, satiabitur panibus: qui autem sectatur otium, stultissimus est. Qui suavis est in vini demorationibus, in suis munitionibus relinquit contumeliam.
verses.notes: The last part of this verse is in the Latin Vulgate and the Douay, but not in some other versions.

verses.textEn: The desire of the impious is the fortification of what is most wicked. But the root of the just shall prosper.
verses.textLa: Desiderium impii munimentum est pessimorum: radix autem iustorum proficiet.

verses.textEn: For the sins of the lips draw ruin to the evil. But the just shall escape from distress.
verses.textLa: Propter peccata labiorum ruina proximat malo: effugiet autem iustus de angustia.

verses.textEn: By the fruit of his own mouth, each one shall be filled with good things, and according to the works of his own hands, it will be distributed to him.
verses.textLa: De fructu oris sui unusquisque replebitur bonis, et iuxta opera manuum suarum retribuetur ei.

verses.textEn: The way of the foolish is right in his own eyes. But whoever is wise listens to counsels.
verses.textLa: Via stulti recta in oculis eius: qui autem sapiens est, audit consilia.

verses.textEn: The senseless immediately reveals his anger. But whoever ignores injuries is clever.
verses.textLa: Fatuus statim indicat iram suam: qui autem dissimulat iniuriam, callidus est.

verses.textEn: He is a sign of justice, who speaks what he knows. But whoever deceives is a dishonest witness.
verses.textLa: Qui quod novit loquitur, index iustitiæ est: qui autem mentitur, testis est fraudulentus.

verses.textEn: He who makes promises is also jabbed, as if with a sword, in conscience. But the tongue of the wise is reasonable.
verses.textLa: Est qui promittit, et quasi gladio pungitur conscientiæ: lingua autem sapientium sanitas est.

verses.textEn: The lips of truth shall be steadfast forever. But a hasty witness readies a lying tongue.
verses.textLa: Labium veritatis firmum erit in perpetuum: qui autem testis est repentinus, concinnat linguam mendacii.

verses.textEn: Deceit is in the heart of those who devise evils. But gladness follows those who take up counsels of peace.
verses.textLa: Dolus in corde cogitantium mala: qui autem pacis ineunt consilia, sequitur eos gaudium.

verses.textEn: Whatever may befall the just, it will not discourage him. But the impious will be filled with disasters.
verses.textLa: Non contristabit iustum quidquid ei acciderit: impii autem replebuntur malo.

verses.textEn: Lying lips are an abomination to the Lord. But whoever acts faithfully pleases him.
verses.textLa: Abominatio est Domino labia mendacia: qui autem fideliter agunt, placent ei.

verses.textEn: A resourceful man conceals knowledge. And the heart of the unwise provokes foolishness.
verses.textLa: Homo versatus celat scientiam: et cor insipientium provocat stultitiam.

verses.textEn: The hand of the strong will rule. But anyone who is neglectful will pay tribute.
verses.textLa: Manus fortium dominabitur: quæ autem remissa est, tributis serviet.

verses.textEn: Grief in the heart of a man humbles him. And with a good word he shall be made glad.
verses.textLa: Mœror in corde viri humiliabit illum, et sermone bono lætificabitur.

verses.textEn: He who ignores a loss for the sake of a friend is just. But the way of the impious will deceive them.
verses.textLa: Qui negligit damnum propter amicum, iustus est: iter autem impiorum decipiet eos.

verses.textEn: The dishonest will not discover gain. But the substance of a man will be like precious gold.
verses.textLa: Non inveniet fraudulentus lucrum: et substantia hominis erit auri pretium.
verses.notes: The Challoner revision reads ‘a just man’ rather than merely ‘a man’. This may be due to a looser translation, or perhaps it represents differences in the source text.

verses.textEn: In the path of justice, there is life. But the devious way leads to death.
verses.textLa: In semita iustitiæ, vita: iter autem devium ducit ad mortem.

verses.textEn: A wise son is the doctrine of his father. But he who ridicules does not listen when he is reproved.
verses.textLa: Filius sapiens, doctrina patris: qui autem illusor est, non audit cum arguitur.

verses.textEn: From the fruit of his own mouth, a man shall be satisfied with good things. But the soul of betrayers is iniquity.
verses.textLa: De fructu oris sui homo satiabitur bonis: anima autem prævaricatorum iniqua.

verses.textEn: Whoever guards his mouth guards his soul. But whoever gives no consideration to his speech shall experience misfortunes.
verses.textLa: Qui custodit os suum, custodit animam suam: qui autem inconsideratus est ad loquendum, sentiet mala.

verses.textEn: The lazy one is willing and then not willing. But the soul of he who labors shall be made fat.
verses.textLa: Vult et non vult piger: anima autem operantium impinguabitur.

verses.textEn: The just shall detest a lying word. But the impious confound and will be confounded.
verses.textLa: Verbum mendax iustus detestabitur: impius autem confundit, et confundetur.

verses.textEn: Justice guards the way of the innocent. But impiety undermines the sinner.
verses.textLa: Iustitia custodit innocentis viam: impietas autem peccatorem supplantat.

verses.textEn: One is like the rich, though he has nothing. And another is like the poor, though he has many riches.
verses.textLa: Est quasi dives cum nihil habeat: et est quasi pauper, cum in multis divitiis sit.

verses.textEn: The redemption of a man’s life is his riches. But he who is poor cannot tolerate correction.
verses.textLa: Redemptio animæ viri, divitiæ suæ: qui autem pauper est, increpationem non sustinet.

verses.textEn: The light of the just enriches. But the lamp of the impious will be extinguished.
verses.textLa: Lux iustorum lætificat: lucerna autem impiorum extinguetur.

verses.textEn: Among the arrogant, there are always conflicts. But those who do everything with counsel are ruled by wisdom.
verses.textLa: Inter superbos semper iurgia sunt: qui autem agunt omnia cum consilio, reguntur sapientia.

verses.textEn: Substance obtained in haste will be diminished. But what is collected by hand, little by little, shall be multiplied.
verses.textLa: Substantia festinata minuetur: quæ autem paulatim colligitur manu, multiplicabitur.

verses.textEn: Hope, when it is delayed, afflicts the soul. The arrival of the desired is a tree of life.
verses.textLa: Spes, quæ differtur, affligit animam: lignum vitæ desiderium veniens.

verses.textEn: Whoever denounces something obligates himself for the future. But whoever fears a lesson shall turn away in peace. Deceitful souls wander into sins. The just are merciful and compassionate.
verses.textLa: Qui detrahit alicui rei, ipse se in futurum obligat: qui autem timet præceptum, in pace versabitur. Animæ dolosæ errant in peccatis: iusti autem misericordes sunt, et miserantur.
verses.notes: Whoever fears being taught a lesson, but making such a mistake, will refrain from denouncing and turn away peacefully.

verses.textEn: The law of the wise is a fountain of life, so that he may turn aside from the ruin of death.
verses.textLa: Lex sapientis fons vitæ, ut declinet a ruina mortis.

verses.textEn: Good doctrine bestows grace. In the way of the contemptuous, there is a chasm.
verses.textLa: Doctrina bona dabit gratiam: in itinere contemptorum vorago.

verses.textEn: The discerning do everything with counsel. But whoever is senseless discloses his stupidity.
verses.textLa: Astutus omnia agit cum consilio: qui autem fatuus est, aperit stultitiam.

verses.textEn: The messenger of the impious will fall into evil. But a faithful ambassador shall prosper.
verses.textLa: Nuncius impii cadet in malum: legatus autem fidelis, sanitas.

verses.textEn: Destitution and disgrace are for those who abandon discipline. But whoever agrees with a reproof shall be glorified.
verses.textLa: Egestas, et ignominia ei, qui deserit disciplinam: qui autem acquiescit arguenti, glorificabitur.

verses.textEn: The desired, when perfected, shall delight the soul. The foolish detest those who flee from evils.
verses.textLa: Desiderium si compleatur, delectat animam: detestantur stulti eos, qui fugiunt mala.
verses.notes: The desired of nations is Jesus Christ, the Messiah. The verse can also be understood more generally, referring to any good that is desired and perfected.

verses.textEn: Whoever keeps step with the wise shall be wise. A friend of the foolish will become like them.
verses.textLa: Qui cum sapientibus graditur, sapiens erit: amicus stultorum similis efficietur.

verses.textEn: Evil pursues sinners. And good things shall be distributed to the just.
verses.textLa: Peccatores persequitur malum: et iustis retribuentur bona.

verses.textEn: The good leave behind heirs: children and grandchildren. And the substance of the sinner is preserved for the just.
verses.textLa: Bonus reliquit heredes filios, et nepotes: et custoditur iusto substantia peccatoris.
verses.notes: The subject of the sentence is ‘bonus’ and it lacks a separate word for ‘man’ (vir). The word ‘filios’ is masculine and refers to sons, but the word ‘nepotes’ is not masculine and refers to grandchildren. Since the word ‘vir’ is lacking and the word ‘nepotes’ is not specific to male descendents, the word filios is translated as children. An alternate translation is equally viable: ‘The good man leaves behind heirs: sons and grandsons.’

verses.textEn: Much nourishment is in the fallow land of the fathers. But for others, it is gathered without judgment.
verses.textLa: Multi cibi in novalibus patrum: et aliis congregantur absque iudicio.

verses.textEn: He who spares the rod hates his son. But he who loves him urgently instructs him.
verses.textLa: Qui parcit virgæ, odit filium suum: qui autem diligit illum, instanter erudit.
