verses.textEn: The just eats and fills his soul. But the belly of the impious is never satisfied.
verses.textLa: Iustus comedit, et replet animam suam: venter autem impiorum insaturabilis.

verses.textEn: A wise woman builds up her household. But a foolish one will pull down with her own hands what has been built up.
verses.textLa: Sapiens mulier ædificat domum suam: insipiens extructam quoque manibus destruet.

verses.textEn: One who walks on a virtuous journey, and who fears God, is despised by him who advances along a disreputable way.
verses.textLa: Ambulans recto itinere, et timens Deum, despicitur ab eo, qui infami graditur via.

verses.textEn: In the mouth of the foolish, there is a rod of arrogance. But the lips of the wise guard them.
verses.textLa: In ore stulti virga superbiæ: labia autem sapientium custodiunt eos.

verses.textEn: Where there are no oxen, the feeding trough is empty. But where there are many crops, there the strength of the ox is manifest.
verses.textLa: Ubi non sunt boves, præsepe vacuum est: ubi autem plurimæ segetes, ibi manifesta est fortitudo bovis.

verses.textEn: A faithful witness will not lie. But a deceitful witness offers a lie.
verses.textLa: Testis fidelis non mentitur: profert autem mendacium dolosus testis.

verses.textEn: A mocker seeks wisdom and does not find it. The doctrine of the prudent is accessible.
verses.textLa: Quærit derisor sapientiam, et non invenit: doctrina prudentium facilis.
verses.notes: The word ‘facilis’ is given in the context of ‘non invenit.’ Therefore, it means ‘easy to find’ or ‘accessible,’ not merely ‘easy.’

verses.textEn: Go against a foolish man, and he does not acknowledge lips of prudence.
verses.textLa: Vade contra virum stultum, et nescit labia prudentiæ.

verses.textEn: The wisdom of a discerning man is to understand his way. And the imprudence of the foolish is to be wandering astray.
verses.textLa: Sapientia callidi est intelligere viam suam: et imprudentia stultorum errans.

verses.textEn: The foolish will speak mockingly of sin. But grace lingers among the just.
verses.textLa: Stultus illudet peccatum, et inter iustos morabitur gratia.

verses.textEn: The heart that knows the bitterness of its own soul, in its gladness the outsider shall not meddle.
verses.textLa: Cor quod novit amaritudinem animæ suæ, in gaudio eius non miscebitur extraneus.

verses.textEn: The house of the impious will be wiped away. Yet truly, the tabernacles of the just shall spring forth.
verses.textLa: Domus impiorum delebitur: tabernacula vero iustorum germinabunt.

verses.textEn: There is a way which seems just to a man, but its conclusion leads to death.
verses.textLa: Est via, quæ videtur homini iusta: novissima autem eius deducunt ad mortem.

verses.textEn: Laughter shall be mingled with sorrow, and mourning occupies the limits of joy.
verses.textLa: Risus dolore miscebitur, et extrema gaudii luctus occupat.

verses.textEn: The foolish will be filled up by his own ways. And the good man shall be above him.
verses.textLa: Viis suis replebitur stultus, et super eum erit vir bonus.

verses.textEn: The innocent trust every word. The astute one considers his own steps. Nothing good will be for the deceitful son. But the wise servant shall act prosperously and his way will be set in order.
verses.textLa: Innocens credit omni verbo: astutus considerat gressus suos. Filio doloso nihil erit boni: servo autem sapienti prosperi erunt actus, et dirigetur via eius.

verses.textEn: The wise fear, and so turn away from evil. The foolish leap ahead with confidence.
verses.textLa: Sapiens timet, et declinat a malo: stultus transilit, et confidit.
verses.notes: Sometimes the word ‘et’ is used in a way in Latin in which the word ‘and’ is not used in English. So, it is translated as ‘with,’ or perhaps even replaced by punctuation, rather than words.

verses.textEn: The impatient will work foolishness. And a resourceful man is hated.
verses.textLa: Impatiens operabitur stultitiam: et vir versutus odiosus est.
verses.notes: A resourceful man knows where to turn for help.

verses.textEn: The childish will possess foolishness, and the discerning will anticipate knowledge.
verses.textLa: Possidebunt parvuli stultitiam, et expectabunt astuti scientiam.
verses.notes: Or, perhaps the first part of this verse has a more positive meaning: ‘the little ones will be masters over foolishness.’

verses.textEn: The evil will fall down before the good. And the impious will fall down before the gates of the just.
verses.textLa: Iacebunt mali ante bonos: et impii ante portas iustorum.

verses.textEn: The pauper will be hated, even by his own neighbor. Yet truly, the friends of the wealthy are many.
verses.textLa: Etiam proximo suo pauper odiosus erit: amici vero divitum multi.

verses.textEn: Whoever despises his neighbor, sins. But whoever pities the poor shall be blessed. Whoever trusts in the Lord loves mercy.
verses.textLa: Qui despicit proximum suum, peccat: qui autem miseretur pauperis, beatus erit. Qui credit in Domino, misericordiam diligit.

verses.textEn: They wander astray who work evil. But mercy and truth prepare good things.
verses.textLa: Errant qui operantur malum: misericordia et veritas præparant bona.

verses.textEn: In every work, there shall be abundance. But where there are many words, there is often need.
verses.textLa: In omni opere erit abundantia: ubi autem verba sunt plurima, ibi frequenter egestas.

verses.textEn: The crown of the wise is their wealth. The senselessness of the foolish is imprudence.
verses.textLa: Corona sapientium, divitiæ eorum: fatuitas stultorum, imprudentia.

verses.textEn: A faithful witness frees souls. And the chameleon utters lies.
verses.textLa: Liberat animas testis fidelis: et profert mendacia versipellis.
verses.notes: The word ‘versipellis’ means ‘shape-shifter,’ or more literally, one who changes his skin: versi-pellis. The word 'chameleon' in English is sometimes applied as a metaphorical description of persons, so it is a fitting translation.

verses.textEn: In the fear of the Lord is the faithfulness of strength, and there shall be hope for his sons.
verses.textLa: In timore Domini fiducia fortitudinis, et filiis eius erit spes.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is a fountain of life, so as to turn aside from the ruin of death.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini fons vitæ, ut declinent a ruina mortis.

verses.textEn: In a multitude of people, there is dignity for the king. And in a paucity of people, there is disgrace for the prince.
verses.textLa: In multitudine populi dignitas regis: et in paucitate plebis ignominia principis.

verses.textEn: Whoever is patient is governed by much prudence. But whoever is impatient exalts his foolishness.
verses.textLa: Qui patiens est, multa gubernatur prudentia: qui autem impatiens est, exaltat stultitiam suam.

verses.textEn: The well-being of the heart is life for the flesh. But envy is decay for the bones.
verses.textLa: Vita carnium, sanitas cordis: putredo ossium, invidia.
verses.notes: The genitive case is not always possessive and is not always to be translated as ‘of.’

verses.textEn: Whoever slanders the indigent argues against his Maker. But he who has compassion on the poor honors his Maker.
verses.textLa: Qui calumniatur egentem, exprobrat Factori eius: honorat autem eum, qui miseretur pauperis.
verses.notes: The pronoun ‘eum’ is here translated with the noun it refers to ‘Factori’ or ‘Maker.’ Otherwise, it would be confusing at to whom the pronoun refers.

verses.textEn: The impious will be expelled in his malice. But the just finds hope even in his own death.
verses.textLa: In malitia sua expelletur impius: sperat autem iustus in morte sua.

verses.textEn: In the heart of the prudent, wisdom finds rest. And so shall he instruct all the uneducated.
verses.textLa: In corde prudentis requiescit sapientia, et indoctos quosque erudiet.

verses.textEn: Justice elevates a nation. But sin makes the peoples miserable.
verses.textLa: Iustitia elevat gentem: miseros autem facit populos peccatum.

verses.textEn: An intelligent minister is acceptable to the king. Whoever is useless shall bear his wrath.
verses.textLa: Acceptus est regi minister intelligens: iracundiam eius inutilis sustinebit.

verses.textEn: A mild response shatters anger. But a harsh word stirs up fury.
verses.textLa: Responsio mollis frangit iram: sermo durus suscitat furorem.

verses.textEn: The tongue of the wise adorns knowledge. But the mouth of the senseless gushes with foolishness.
verses.textLa: Lingua sapientium ornat scientiam: os fatuorum ebullit stultitiam.

verses.textEn: In every place, the eyes of the Lord consider good and evil.
verses.textLa: In omni loco oculi Domini contemplantur bonos et malos.

verses.textEn: A peaceful tongue is a tree of life. But that which is immoderate will crush the spirit.
verses.textLa: Lingua placabilis, lignum vitæ: quæ autem immoderata est, conteret spiritum.

verses.textEn: A fool laughs at the discipline of his father. But whoever preserves rebukes will become astute. In abundant justice, there is very great virtue. But the intentions of the impious will be eradicated.
verses.textLa: Stultus irridet disciplinam patris sui: qui autem custodit increpationes, astutior fiet. In abundanti iustitia virtus maxima est: cogitationes autem impiorum eradicabuntur.

verses.textEn: The house of the just has very great strength. And in the fruits of the impious, there is disorder.
verses.textLa: Domus iusti plurima fortitudo: et in fructibus impii conturbatio.

verses.textEn: The lips of the wise shall disseminate knowledge. The heart of the foolish will be dissimilar.
verses.textLa: Labia sapientium disseminabunt scientiam: cor stultorum dissimile erit.

verses.textEn: The sacrifices of the impious are abominable to the Lord. The vows of the just are appeasing.
verses.textLa: Victimæ impiorum abominabiles Domino: vota iustorum placabilia:

verses.textEn: The way of the impious is an abomination to the Lord. Whoever pursues justice is loved by him.
verses.textLa: Abominatio est Domino via impii: qui sequitur iustitiam, diligitur ab eo.

verses.textEn: Doctrine is evil to those who abandon the way of life. Whoever hates correction shall die.
verses.textLa: Doctrina mala deserenti viam vitæ: qui increpationes odit, morietur.

verses.textEn: Hell and perdition are in the sight of the Lord. How much more the hearts of the sons of men!
verses.textLa: Infernus, et perditio coram Domino: quanto magis corda filiorum hominum!

verses.textEn: He who corrupts himself does not love the one who afflicts him, nor will he step toward the wise.
verses.textLa: Non amat pestilens eum, qui se corripit: nec ad sapientes graditur.

verses.textEn: A rejoicing heart gladdens the face. But by the grief of the soul, the spirit is cast down.
verses.textLa: Cor gaudens exhilarat faciem: in mœrore animi deiicitur spiritus.

verses.textEn: The heart of the wise seeks doctrine. And the mouth of the foolish feeds on ignorance.
verses.textLa: Cor sapientis quærit doctrinam: et os stultorum pascitur imperitia.

verses.textEn: All the days of the poor are evil. A secure mind is like a continual feast.
verses.textLa: Omnes dies pauperis, mali: secura mens quasi iuge convivium.

verses.textEn: Better is a little with the fear of the Lord, than great treasures and dissatisfaction.
verses.textLa: Melius est parum cum timore Domini, quam thesauri magni et insatiabiles.

verses.textEn: It is better to be called to vegetables with charity, than to a fatted calf with hatred.
verses.textLa: Melius est vocari ad olera cum charitate: quam ad vitulum saginatum cum odio.

verses.textEn: A short-tempered man provokes conflicts. Whoever is patient tempers those who are stirred up.
verses.textLa: Vir iracundus provocat rixas: qui patiens est, mitigat suscitatas.

verses.textEn: The way of the slothful is like a hedge of thorns. The way of the just is without offense.
verses.textLa: Iter pigrorum quasi sepes spinarum: via iustorum absque offendiculo.

verses.textEn: A wise son gladdens the father. But the foolish man despises his mother.
verses.textLa: Filius sapiens lætificat patrem: et stultus homo despicit matrem suam.

verses.textEn: Folly is gladness to the foolish. And the prudent man sets his own steps in order.
verses.textLa: Stultitia gaudium stulto: et vir prudens dirigit gressus suos.

verses.textEn: Intentions dissipate where there is no counsel. Yet truly, they are confirmed where there are many counselors.
verses.textLa: Dissipantur cogitationes ubi non est consilium: ubi vero sunt plures consiliarii, confirmantur.

verses.textEn: A man rejoices in the verdict of his own mouth. And a word at the right time is best.
verses.textLa: Lætatur homo in sententia oris sui: et sermo opportunus est optimus.

verses.textEn: The path of life is for the wise above, so that he may turn away from the end of Hell.
verses.textLa: Semita vitæ super eruditum, ut declinet de inferno novissimo.
verses.notes: Or, ‘the finality of Hell,’ or ‘a conclusion in Hell,’ or ‘the deepest part of Hell,’ or ‘an ending in Hell.’ The wise are above ground, i.e. they are alive.

verses.textEn: The Lord will demolish the house of the arrogant. And He will make firm the borders of the widow.
verses.textLa: Domum superborum demolietur Dominus: et firmos faciet terminos viduæ.

verses.textEn: Evil intentions are an abomination to the Lord. And pure conversation, most beautiful, shall be confirmed by him.
verses.textLa: Abominatio Domini cogitationes malæ: et purus sermo pulcherrimus firmabitur ab eo.

verses.textEn: Whoever pursues avarice disturbs his own house. But whoever hates bribes shall live. Through mercy and faith, sins are purged. But through the fear of the Lord, each one turns aside from evil.
verses.textLa: Conturbat domum suam qui sectatur avaritiam: qui autem odit munera, vivet. Per misericordiam et fidem purgantur peccata: per timorem autem Domini declinat omnis a malo.

verses.textEn: The mind of the just meditates on obedience. The mouth of the impious overflows with evils.
verses.textLa: Mens iusti meditatur obedientiam: os impiorum redundat malis.

verses.textEn: The Lord is distant from the impious. And he will heed the prayers of the just.
verses.textLa: Longe est Dominus ab impiis: et orationes iustorum exaudiet.

verses.textEn: The light of the eyes rejoices the soul. A good reputation fattens the bones.
verses.textLa: Lux oculorum lætificat animam: fama bona impinguat ossa.

verses.textEn: The ear that listens to the reproofs of life shall abide in the midst of the wise.
verses.textLa: Auris, quæ audit increpationes vitæ, in medio sapientium commorabitur.

verses.textEn: Whoever rejects discipline despises his own soul. But whoever agrees to correction is a possessor of the heart.
verses.textLa: Qui abiicit disciplinam, despicit animam suam: qui autem acquiescit increpationibus, possessor est cordis.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is the discipline of wisdom. And humility precedes glory.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini, disciplina sapientiæ: et gloriam præcedit humilitas.

verses.textEn: It is for man to prepare the soul, and for the Lord to govern the tongue.
verses.textLa: Hominis est animam præparare: et Domini gubernare linguam.
verses.notes: Again, the genitive case is not always possessive and is not always to be translated as ‘of.’

verses.textEn: All the ways of a man are open to his eyes; the Lord is the one who weighs spirits.
verses.textLa: Omnes viæ hominis patent oculis eius: spirituum ponderator est Dominus.

verses.textEn: Open your works to the Lord, and your intentions will be set in order.
verses.textLa: Revela Domino opera tua, et dirigentur cogitationes tuæ.

verses.textEn: The Lord has wrought all things because of himself. Likewise the impious is for the evil day.
verses.textLa: Universa propter semetipsum operatus est Dominus: impium quoque ad diem malum.

verses.textEn: All the arrogant are an abomination to the Lord. Even if hand will be joined to hand, he is not innocent. The beginning of a good way is to do justice. And this is more acceptable with God than to immolate sacrifices.
verses.textLa: Abominatio Domini est omnis arrogans: etiam si manus ad manum fuerit, non est innocens. Initium viæ bonæ, facere iustitiam: accepta est autem apud Deum magis, quam immolare hostias.

verses.textEn: By mercy and truth, iniquity is redeemed. And by the fear of the Lord, one turns away from evil.
verses.textLa: Misericordia et veritate redimitur iniquitas: et in timore Domini declinatur a malo.

verses.textEn: When the ways of man will please the Lord, he will convert even his enemies to peace.
verses.textLa: Cum placuerint Domino viæ hominis, inimicos quoque eius convertet ad pacem.

verses.textEn: Better is a little with justice, than many fruits with iniquity.
verses.textLa: Melius est parum cum iustitia, quam multi fructus cum iniquitate.

verses.textEn: The heart of man disposes his way. But it is for Lord to direct his steps.
verses.textLa: Cor hominis disponit viam suam: sed Domini est dirigere gressus eius.

verses.textEn: Foreknowledge is in the lips of the king. His mouth shall not err in judgment.
verses.textLa: Divinatio in labiis regis, in iudicio non errabit os eius.

verses.textEn: Weights and scales are judgments of the Lord. And all the stones in the bag are his work.
verses.textLa: Pondus et statera iudicia Domini sunt: et opera eius omnes lapides sacculi.

verses.textEn: Those who act impiously are abominable to the king. For the throne is made firm by justice.
verses.textLa: Abominabiles regi qui agunt impie: quoniam iustitia firmatur solium.

verses.textEn: Just lips are the will of kings. He who speaks honestly shall be loved.
verses.textLa: Voluntas regum labia iusta: qui recta loquitur, diligetur:
verses.notes: Or, who speaks forthrightly or directly or honestly.

verses.textEn: The indignation of a king is a herald of death. And the wise man will appease it.
verses.textLa: Indignatio regis, nuncii mortis: et vir sapiens placabit eam.

verses.textEn: In the cheerfulness of the king’s countenance, there is life. And his clemency is like belated rain.
verses.textLa: In hilaritate vultus regis, vita: et clementia eius quasi imber serotinus.

verses.textEn: Possess wisdom, for it is better than gold. And acquire prudence, for it is more precious than silver.
verses.textLa: Posside sapientiam, quia auro melior est: et acquire prudentiam, quia pretiosior est argento.
verses.notes: Prudence is found in the practical application of wisdom.

verses.textEn: The path of the just turns away from evils. He who guards his soul preserves his way.
verses.textLa: Semita iustorum declinat mala: custos animæ suæ servat viam suam.

verses.textEn: Arrogance precedes destruction. And the spirit is exalted before a fall.
verses.textLa: Contritionem præcedit superbia: et ante ruinam exaltatur spiritus.

verses.textEn: It is better to be humbled with the meek, than to divide spoils with the arrogant.
verses.textLa: Melius est humiliari cum mitibus, quam dividere spolia cum superbis.

verses.textEn: The learned in word shall find good things. And whoever hopes in the Lord is blessed.
verses.textLa: Eruditus in verbo reperiet bona: et qui sperat in Domino, beatus est.

verses.textEn: Whoever is wise in heart shall be called prudent. And whoever is sweet in eloquence shall attain to what is greater.
verses.textLa: Qui sapiens est corde, appellabitur prudens: et qui dulcis eloquio, maiora percipiet.

verses.textEn: Learning is a fountain of life to one who possesses it. The doctrine of the foolish is senseless.
verses.textLa: Fons vitæ eruditio possidentis: doctrina stultorum fatuitas.

verses.textEn: The heart of the wise shall instruct his mouth and add grace to his lips.
verses.textLa: Cor sapientis erudiet os eius: et labiis eius addet gratiam.

verses.textEn: Careful words are a honeycomb: sweet to the soul and healthful to the bones.
verses.textLa: Favus mellis, composita verba: dulcedo animæ, sanitas ossium.

verses.textEn: There is a way which seems right to a man, and its end result leads to death.
verses.textLa: Est via quæ videtur homini recta: et novissima eius ducunt ad mortem.

verses.textEn: The soul of the laborer labors for himself, because his mouth has driven him to it.
verses.textLa: Anima laborantis laborat sibi, quia compulit eum os suum:

verses.textEn: The impious man digs up evil, and in his lips is a burning fire.
verses.textLa: Vir impius fodit malum, et in labiis eius ignis ardescit.

verses.textEn: A perverse man stirs up lawsuits. And one who is verbose divides leaders.
verses.textLa: Homo perversus suscitat lites: et verbosus separat principes.

verses.textEn: A man of iniquity entices his friend, and he leads him along a way that is not good.
verses.textLa: Vir iniquus lactat amicum suum: et ducit eum per viam non bonam.

verses.textEn: Whoever, with astonished eyes, thinks up depravities, biting his lips, accomplishes evil.
verses.textLa: Qui attonitis oculis cogitat prava, mordens labia sua, perficit malum.

verses.textEn: Old age is a crown of dignity, when it is found in the ways of justice.
verses.textLa: Corona dignitatis senectus, quæ in viis iustitiæ reperietur.

verses.textEn: A patient man is better than a strong one. And whoever rules his soul is better than one who assaults cities.
verses.textLa: Melior est patiens viro forti: et qui dominatur animo suo, expugnatore urbium.

verses.textEn: Lots are cast into the lap, but they are tempered by the Lord.
verses.textLa: Sortes mittuntur in sinum, sed a Domino temperantur.

verses.textEn: A dry morsel with gladness is better than a house full of sacrifices along with conflict.
verses.textLa: Melior est buccella sicca cum gaudio, quam domus plena victimis cum iurgio.

verses.textEn: A wise servant shall rule over foolish sons, and he will divide the inheritance among brothers.
verses.textLa: Servus sapiens dominabitur filiis stultis, et inter fratres hereditatem dividet.

verses.textEn: Just as silver is tested by fire, and gold is tested in the furnace, so also does the Lord test hearts.
verses.textLa: Sicut igne probatur argentum, et aurum camino: ita corda probat Dominus.

verses.textEn: The evil obey an unjust tongue. And the false are submissive to lying lips.
verses.textLa: Malus obedit linguæ iniquæ: et fallax obtemperat labiis mendacibus.

verses.textEn: Whoever despises the poor rebukes his Maker. And whoever rejoices in the ruin of another will not go unpunished.
verses.textLa: Qui despicit pauperem, exprobrat Factori eius: et qui ruina lætatur alterius, non erit impunitus.

verses.textEn: Sons of sons are the crown of old age. And the glory of sons is their fathers.
verses.textLa: Corona senum filii filiorum: et gloria filiorum patres eorum.

verses.textEn: Well-chosen words are not fitting for the foolish, nor are lying lips fitting for a leader.
verses.textLa: Non decent stultum verba composita: nec principem labium mentiens.

verses.textEn: The expectation of those who stand ready is a most pleasing jewel. Whichever way he turns himself, he understands prudently.
verses.textLa: Gemma gratissima, expectatio præstolantis: quocumque se vertit, prudenter intelligit.

verses.textEn: Whoever conceals an offense seeks friendships. Whoever repeats the words of another separates allies.
verses.textLa: Qui celat delictum, quærit amicitias: qui altero sermone repetit, separat fœderatos.

verses.textEn: A correction benefits more with a wise man, than a hundred stripes with a fool.
verses.textLa: Plus proficit correptio apud prudentem, quam centum plagæ apud stultum.

verses.textEn: The evil one continually seeks conflicts. But a cruel Angel shall be sent against him.
verses.textLa: Semper iurgia quærit malus: Angelus autem crudelis mittetur contra eum.

verses.textEn: It is more expedient to meet a bear robbed of her young, than the foolish trusting in his own folly.
verses.textLa: Expedit magis ursæ occurrere raptis fœtibus, quam fatuo confidenti in stultitia sua.

verses.textEn: Whoever repays evil for good, evil shall not withdraw from his house.
verses.textLa: Qui reddit mala pro bonis, non recedet malum de domo eius.

verses.textEn: Whoever releases the water is the head of the conflict. And just before he suffers contempt, he abandons judgment.
verses.textLa: Qui dimittit aquam, caput est iurgiorum: et antequam patiatur contumeliam, iudicium deserit.

verses.textEn: Those who justify the impious, and those who condemn the just, both are abominable with God.
verses.textLa: Qui iustificat impium, et qui condemnat iustum, abominabilis est uterque apud Deum.

verses.textEn: What does it profit the foolish to have riches, when he is not able to buy wisdom? Whoever makes his house high seeks ruin. And whoever shuns learning shall fall into evils.
verses.textLa: Quid prodest stulto habere divitias, cum sapientiam emere non possit? Qui altum facit domum suam, quærit ruinam: et qui evitat discere, incidet in mala.

verses.textEn: Whoever is a friend loves at all times. And a brother is proved by distress.
verses.textLa: Omni tempore diligit qui amicus est: et frater in angustiis comprobatur.

verses.textEn: A foolish man will clap his hands, when he makes a pledge for his friend.
verses.textLa: Stultus homo plaudet manibus cum spoponderit pro amico suo.

verses.textEn: Whoever dwells on discord loves disputes. And whoever exalts his door seeks ruin.
verses.textLa: Qui meditatur discordias, diligit rixas: et qui exaltat ostium, quærit ruinam.

verses.textEn: Whoever is of a perverse heart shall not find good. And whoever turns his tongue shall fall into evil.
verses.textLa: Qui perversi cordis est, non inveniet bonum: et qui vertit linguam, incidet in malum.

verses.textEn: A foolish one is born into his own disgrace. But his father will not rejoice in one who is senseless.
verses.textLa: Natus est stultus in ignominiam suam: sed nec pater in fatuo lætabitur.

verses.textEn: A joyful soul makes a lifetime flourish. A gloomy spirit dries out the bones.
verses.textLa: Animus gaudens ætatem floridam facit: spiritus tristis exiccat ossa.

verses.textEn: The impious receives gifts from the bosom, so that he may pervert the paths of judgment.
verses.textLa: Munera de sinu impius accipit, ut pervertat semitas iudicii.

verses.textEn: Prudence shines from the face of the wise. The eyes of the foolish are on the ends of the earth.
verses.textLa: In facie prudentis lucet sapientia: oculi stultorum in finibus terræ.

verses.textEn: A foolish son is the anger of the father and the grief of the mother who conceived him.
verses.textLa: Ira patris, filius stultus: et dolor matris quæ genuit eum.

verses.textEn: It is not good to inflict damage on the just, nor to strike the leader who judges uprightly.
verses.textLa: Non est bonum, damnum inferre iusto: nec percutere principem, qui recta iudicat.

verses.textEn: Whoever moderates his words is learned and prudent. And a man of learning has a precious spirit.
verses.textLa: Qui moderatur sermones suos, doctus et prudens est: et pretiosi spiritus vir eruditus.

verses.textEn: If he would remain silent, even the foolish would be considered wise, and if he closes his lips, intelligent.
verses.textLa: Stultus quoque si tacuerit, sapiens reputabitur: et si compresserit labia sua, intelligens.

verses.textEn: Whoever has a will to withdraw from a friend, seeks occasions; he shall be reproached at all times.
verses.textLa: Occasiones quærit qui vult recedere ab amico: omni tempore erit exprobrabilis.

verses.textEn: The foolish do not accept words of prudence, unless you say what is already turning in his heart.
verses.textLa: Non recipit stultus verba prudentiæ: nisi ea dixeris quæ versantur in corde eius.

verses.textEn: The impious, when he has arrived within the depths of sin, thinks little of it. But ill repute and disgrace follow him.
verses.textLa: Impius, cum in profundum venerit peccatorum, contemnit: sed sequitur eum ignominia et opprobrium.

verses.textEn: Words from the mouth of a man are deep waters. And the fountain of wisdom is a torrent overflowing.
verses.textLa: Aqua profunda verba ex ore viri: et torrens redundans fons sapientiæ.

verses.textEn: It is not good to accept the character of the impious, so as to turn away from true judgment.
verses.textLa: Accipere personam impii non est bonum, ut declines a veritate iudicii.

verses.textEn: The lips of the foolish meddle in disputes. And his mouth provokes conflicts.
verses.textLa: Labia stulti miscent se rixis: et os eius iurgia provocat.

verses.textEn: The mouth of the foolish is his destruction, and his own lips are the ruin of his soul.
verses.textLa: Os stulti contritio eius: et labia ipsius, ruina animæ eius.

verses.textEn: The words of the double-tongued seem simple. And they reach even to the interior of the gut. Fear casts down the lazy, but the souls of the effeminate shall go hungry.
verses.textLa: Verba bilinguis, quasi simplicia: et ipsa perveniunt usque ad interiora ventris. Pigrum deiicit timor: animæ autem effeminatorum esurient.

verses.textEn: Whoever is dissolute and slack in his work is the brother of him who wastes his own works.
verses.textLa: Qui mollis et dissolutus est in opere suo, frater est sua opera dissipantis.

verses.textEn: The name of the Lord is a very strong tower. The just one rushes to it, and he shall be exalted.
verses.textLa: Turris fortissima, nomen Domini: ad ipsum currit iustus, et exaltabitur.

verses.textEn: The substance of the wealthy is the city of his strength, and it is like a strong wall encircling him.
verses.textLa: Substantia divitis urbs roboris eius, et quasi murus validus circumdans eum.
verses.notes: A different Latin word is used in this verse, to describe the strength of riches, than is used in the previous verse to describe the strength of calling upon the name of the Lord. These are two different kinds of strength.

verses.textEn: The heart of a man is exalted before it is crushed and humbled before it is glorified.
verses.textLa: Antequam conteratur, exaltatur cor hominis: et antequam glorificetur, humiliatur.
verses.notes: This verse applies to the contemplative way.

verses.textEn: Whoever responds before he listens, demonstrates himself to be foolish and deserving of confusion.
verses.textLa: Qui prius respondet quam audiat, stultum se esse demonstrat, et confusione dignum.

verses.textEn: The spirit of a man sustains his weakness. Yet who can sustain a spirit that is easily angered?
verses.textLa: Spiritus viri sustentat imbecillitatem suam: spiritum vero ad irascendum facilem quis poterit sustinere?

verses.textEn: A prudent heart shall possess knowledge. And the ear of the wise seeks doctrine.
verses.textLa: Cor prudens possidebit scientiam: et auris sapientium quærit doctrinam.

verses.textEn: A man’s gift expands his way and makes space for him before leaders.
verses.textLa: Donum hominis dilatat viam eius, et ante principes spatium ei facit.

verses.textEn: The just is the first accuser of himself; his friend arrives and shall investigate him.
verses.textLa: Iustus, prior est accusator sui: venit amicus eius, et investigabit eum.

verses.textEn: Casting a lot suppresses contentions and passes judgment, even among the powerful.
verses.textLa: Contradictiones comprimit sors, et inter potentes quoque diiudicat.

verses.textEn: A brother who is helped by a brother is like a reinforced city, and judgments are like the bars of cities.
verses.textLa: Frater, qui adiuvatur a fratre, quasi civitas firma: et iudicia quasi vectes urbium.

verses.textEn: From the fruit of a man’s mouth shall his belly be filled. And the harvest of his own lips shall satisfy him.
verses.textLa: De fructu oris viri replebitur venter eius: et genimina labiorum ipsius saturabunt eum.
verses.notes: The word ‘harvest’ is a looser translation of ‘genimina,’ because the latter is clearly a continuation of the metaphor from earlier in the same verse. There is the fruit of a man’s mouth and the ‘genimina’ (spouts, shoots, vegetables, crops, produce, etc.). The translation of harvest makes the verse more comprehensible in English than any of the more literal translation choices.

verses.textEn: Death and life are in the power of the tongue. Whoever values it shall eat from its fruits.
verses.textLa: Mors, et vita in manu linguæ: qui diligunt eam, comedent fructus eius.

verses.textEn: He who has found a good wife has found goodness, and he shall draw contentment from the Lord. He who expels a good wife expels goodness. But he who holds on to an adulteress is foolish and impious.
verses.textLa: Qui invenit mulierem bonam, invenit bonum: et hauriet iucunditatem a Domino. Qui expellit mulierem bonam, expellit bonum: qui autem tenet adulteram, stultus est et impius.
verses.notes: He who has found a good wife has not merely found a good thing, he has found goodness itself, a reflection within his wife of God who is Goodness, and so he shall draw contentment from God himself.

verses.textEn: The poor will speak with supplications. And the rich will express themselves roughly.
verses.textLa: Cum obsecrationibus loquetur pauper: et dives effabitur rigide.

verses.textEn: A man amiable to society shall be more friendly than a brother.
verses.textLa: Vir amabilis ad societatem, magis amicus erit, quam frater.

verses.textEn: Better is the poor who walks in his simplicity, than the rich who twists his lips and is unwise.
verses.textLa: Melior est pauper, qui ambulat in simplicitate sua, quam dives torquens labia sua, et insipiens.

verses.textEn: Where there is no knowledge of the soul, there is no good. And whoever hurries with his feet will stumble.
verses.textLa: Ubi non est scientia animæ, non est bonum: et qui festinus est pedibus, offendet.

verses.textEn: The foolishness of a man undermines his steps. And then he seethes in his soul against God.
verses.textLa: Stultitia hominis supplantat gressus eius: et contra Deum fervet animo suo.

verses.textEn: Riches add many friends. But from the pauper, even those whom he had become separated.
verses.textLa: Divitiæ addunt amicos plurimos: a paupere autem et hi, quos habuit, separantur.

verses.textEn: A false witness shall not go unpunished. And whoever speaks lies will not escape.
verses.textLa: Testis falsus non erit impunitus: et qui mendacia loquitur, non effugiet.

verses.textEn: Many honor the character of one who is powerful, and there are friends for a giver of gifts.
verses.textLa: Multi colunt personam potentis, et amici sunt dona tribuentis.

verses.textEn: The brothers of the poor man hate him. Moreover, even his friends have withdrawn far from him. Whoever pursues only words shall have nothing.
verses.textLa: Fratres hominis pauperis oderunt eum: insuper et amici procul recesserunt ab eo. Qui tantum verba sectatur, nihil habebit:

verses.textEn: But whoever possesses reason loves his own soul. And one who guards prudence shall discover good things.
verses.textLa: qui autem possessor est mentis, diligit animam suam, et custos prudentiæ inveniet bona.

verses.textEn: A false witness shall not go unpunished. And whoever speaks lies will perish.
verses.textLa: Falsus testis non erit impunitus: et qui loquitur mendacia, peribit.

verses.textEn: Fine things are not fitting for the foolish, nor is it fitting for a servant to rule over princes.
verses.textLa: Non decent stultum deliciæ: nec servum dominari principibus.

verses.textEn: The doctrine of a man is known through patience. And his glory is to pass beyond iniquities.
verses.textLa: Doctrina viri per patientiam noscitur: et gloria eius est iniqua prætergredi.

verses.textEn: Like the roaring of a lion, so also is the wrath of a king. And his cheerfulness is like the dew upon the grass.
verses.textLa: Sicut fremitus leonis, ita et regis ira: et sicut ros super herbam, ita et hilaritas eius.

verses.textEn: A foolish son is the grief of his father. And an argumentative wife is like a roof that is continually leaking.
verses.textLa: Dolor patris, filius stultus: et tecta iugiter perstillantia, litigiosa mulier.
verses.notes: Literally, ‘perstillantia’ means ‘dripping through,’ i.e. leaking.

verses.textEn: A house and its riches are given by parents. But a prudent wife is particularly from the Lord.
verses.textLa: Domus, et divitiæ dantur a parentibus: a Domino autem proprie uxor prudens.

verses.textEn: Laziness sends one into a deep sleep, and a dissolute soul will go hungry.
verses.textLa: Pigredo immittit soporem, et anima dissoluta esuriet.

verses.textEn: Whoever guards a commandment guards his own soul. But whoever neglects his own way will die.
verses.textLa: Qui custodit mandatum, custodit animam suam: qui autem negligit viam suam, mortificabitur.

verses.textEn: Whoever is merciful to the poor lends to the Lord. And he will repay him for his efforts.
verses.textLa: Fœneratur Domino qui miseretur pauperis: et vicissitudinem suam reddet ei.

verses.textEn: Teach your son; do not despair. But do not set your soul toward putting him to death.
verses.textLa: Erudi filium tuum, ne desperes: ad interfectionem autem eius ne ponas animam tuam.

verses.textEn: Whoever is impatient will sustain damage. And when it has been taken away, he will set up another.
verses.textLa: Qui impatiens est, sustinebit damnum: et cum rapuerit, aliud apponet.

verses.textEn: Listen to counsel and take up discipline, so that you may be wise in your latter days.
verses.textLa: Audi consilium, et suscipe disciplinam, ut sis sapiens in novissimis tuis.

verses.textEn: There are many intentions in the heart of a man. But the will of the Lord shall stand firm.
verses.textLa: Multæ cogitationes in corde viri: voluntas autem Domini permanebit.

verses.textEn: An indigent man is merciful. And a pauper is better than a deceitful man.
verses.textLa: Homo indigens misericors est: et melior est pauper quam vir mendax.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is unto life. And he shall linger in plentitude, without being visited by disaster.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini ad vitam: et in plenitudine commorabitur, absque visitatione pessima.
verses.notes: The word ‘pessima’ like the word ‘mala’ can refer to what is wicked or evil, but it can also refer to disaster or misfortune.

verses.textEn: The lazy conceals his hand under his arm, and he will not so much as bring it to his mouth.
verses.textLa: Abscondit piger manum suam sub ascella, nec ad os suum applicat eam.

verses.textEn: When the pestilent are scourged, the foolish will become wiser. But if you chastise the wise, he will understand discipline.
verses.textLa: Pestilente flagellato stultus sapientior erit: si autem corripueris sapientem, intelliget disciplinam.

verses.textEn: Whoever afflicts his father and flees from his mother is disreputable and unhappy.
verses.textLa: Qui affligit patrem, et fugat matrem, ignominiosus est et infelix.

verses.textEn: Son, do not cease listening to doctrine, and do not be ignorant of the sermons of knowledge.
verses.textLa: Non cesses fili audire doctrinam, nec ignores sermones scientiæ.

verses.textEn: An unjust witness ridicules judgment. And the mouth of the impious devours iniquity.
verses.textLa: Testis iniquus deridet iudicium: et os impiorum devorat iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: Judgments are prepared for those who ridicule. And striking hammers are prepared for the bodies of the foolish.
verses.textLa: Parata sunt derisoribus iudicia: et mallei percutientes stultorum corporibus.

verses.textEn: It is a luxurious thing, wine, and inebriation is tumultuous. Anyone who is delighted by this will not be wise.
verses.textLa: Luxuriosa res, vinum, et tumultuosa ebrietas: quicumque his delectatur, non erit sapiens.

verses.textEn: Just like the roaring of a lion, so also is the dread of a king. Whoever provokes him sins in his own soul.
verses.textLa: Sicut rugitus leonis, ita et terror regis: qui provocat eum, peccat in animam suam.

verses.textEn: Honor is for the man who separates himself from contentions. But all the foolish meddle in altercations.
verses.textLa: Honor est homini, qui separat se a contentionibus: omnes autem stulti miscentur contumeliis.

verses.textEn: Because of the cold, the lazy one was not willing to plough. Therefore, in the summer, he will beg, and it will not be given to him.
verses.textLa: Propter frigus piger arare noluit: mendicabit ergo æstate, et non dabitur illi.

verses.textEn: Counsel in the heart of a man is like deep waters. But a wise man will draw it out.
verses.textLa: Sicut aqua profunda, sic consilium in corde viri: sed homo sapiens exhauriet illud.

verses.textEn: Many men are called merciful. But who will find a faithful man?
verses.textLa: Multi homines misericordes vocantur: virum autem fidelem quis inveniet?

verses.textEn: The just who walks in his simplicity shall leave behind him blessed sons.
verses.textLa: Iustus, qui ambulat in simplicitate sua, beatos post se filios derelinquet.

verses.textEn: The king who sits on the throne of judgment scatters all evil with his gaze.
verses.textLa: Rex, qui sedet in solio iudicii, dissipat omne malum intuitu suo.

verses.textEn: Who is able to say: “My heart is clean. I am pure from sin?”
verses.textLa: Quis potest dicere: Mundum est cor meum, purus sum a peccato?

verses.textEn: Diverse weights, diverse measures: both are abominable with God.
verses.textLa: Pondus et pondus, mensura et mensura: utrumque abominabile est apud Deum.

verses.textEn: A child may be understood by his interests: whether his works may be clean and upright.
verses.textLa: Ex studiis suis intelligitur puer, si munda et recta sint opera eius.

verses.textEn: The hearing ear and the seeing eye: the Lord has made them both.
verses.textLa: Aurem audientem, et oculum videntem, Dominus fecit utrumque.

verses.textEn: Do not love sleep, lest deprivation oppress you. Open your eyes and be satisfied with bread.
verses.textLa: Noli diligere somnum, ne te egestas opprimat: aperi oculos tuos, et saturare panibus.

verses.textEn: “It is bad, it is bad,” says every buyer; and when he has withdrawn, then he will boast.
verses.textLa: Malum est, malum est, dicit omnis emptor: et cum recesserit, tunc gloriabitur.

verses.textEn: There is gold, and there are a multitude of jewels. But lips of knowledge are a precious vessel.
verses.textLa: Est aurum, et multitudo gemmarum: et vas pretiosum labia scientiæ.

verses.textEn: Take away the vestments of him who stands up to vouch for a stranger, and take a pledge from him instead of from outsiders.
verses.textLa: Tolle vestimentum eius, qui fideiussor extitit alieni, et pro extraneis aufer pignus ab eo.

verses.textEn: The bread of lies is sweet to a man. But afterwards, his mouth will be filled with pebbles.
verses.textLa: Suavis est homini panis mendacii: et postea implebitur os eius calculo.

verses.textEn: Plans are strengthened by counsels. And wars are to be handled by governments.
verses.textLa: Cogitationes consiliis roborantur: et gubernaculis tractanda sunt bella.

verses.textEn: Do not become involved with him who reveals mysteries, and who walks deceitfully, and who enlarges his lips.
verses.textLa: Ei, qui revelat mysteria, et ambulat fraudulenter, et dilatat labia sua, ne commiscearis.

verses.textEn: Whoever curses his father and mother, his lamp will be extinguished in the midst of darkness.
verses.textLa: Qui maledicit patri suo, et matri, extinguetur lucerna eius in mediis tenebris.

verses.textEn: When an inheritance is obtained hastily in the beginning, in the end it will be without a blessing.
verses.textLa: Hereditas, ad quam festinatur in principio, in novissimo benedictione carebit.

verses.textEn: Do not say, “I will repay evil.” Wait for the Lord, and he will free you.
verses.textLa: Ne dicas: Reddam malum: expecta Dominum, et liberabit te.

verses.textEn: Diverse weights are an abomination with the Lord. A deceitful balance is not good.
verses.textLa: Abominatio est apud Dominum pondus et pondus: statera dolosa non est bona.

verses.textEn: The steps of men are directed by the Lord. But who is the man able to understand his own way?
verses.textLa: A Domino diriguntur gressus viri: quis autem hominum intelligere potest viam suam?

verses.textEn: It is ruin for a man to devour what is holy, or, after making vows, to retract them.
verses.textLa: Ruina est homini devorare sanctos, et post vota retractare.

verses.textEn: A wise king scatters the impious and bends an archway over them.
verses.textLa: Dissipat impios rex sapiens, et incurvat super eos fornicem.

verses.textEn: The spirit of a man is a lamp to the Lord, which investigates all the secrets of the inner self.
verses.textLa: Lucerna Domini spiraculum hominis, quæ investigat omnia secreta ventris.

verses.textEn: Mercy and truth guard the king, and his throne is strengthened by clemency.
verses.textLa: Misericordia, et veritas custodiunt regem, et roboratur clementia thronus eius.

verses.textEn: The joy of youths is their strength. And the dignity of old men is their grey hairs.
verses.textLa: Exultatio iuvenum, fortitudo eorum: et dignitas senum canities.

verses.textEn: The bruise of a wound, as well as scourges, shall wipe away evils in the more secret places of the inner self.
verses.textLa: Livor vulneris absterget mala: et plagæ in secretioribus ventris.
verses.notes: The second part of this verse is to be understood as combining with the first, as if to say: “The bruise of a wound shall wipe away evils, and scourges shall wipe away evils, in the more secret places of the inner self.”

verses.textEn: Just as with the dividing of the waters, so also is the heart of the king in the hand of the Lord. He shall bend it whichever way he wills.
verses.textLa: Sicut divisiones aquarum, ita cor regis in manu Domini: quocumque voluerit, inclinabit illud.

verses.textEn: Every way of a man seems right to himself. But the Lord weighs hearts.
verses.textLa: Omnis via viri recta sibi videtur: appendit autem corda Dominus.

verses.textEn: To do mercy and judgment is more pleasing to the Lord than sacrifices.
verses.textLa: Facere misericordiam et iudicium, magis placet Domino quam victimæ.

verses.textEn: To lift up the eyes is to enlarge the heart. The lamp of the impious is sin.
verses.textLa: Exaltatio oculorum est dilatatio cordis: lucerna impiorum peccatum.

verses.textEn: The intentions of the robust continually bring forth abundance. But all the lazy are continually in need.
verses.textLa: Cogitationes robusti semper in abundantia: omnis autem piger semper in egestate est.

verses.textEn: Whoever gathers treasures by a lying tongue is vain and heartless. And he will stumble into the snares of death.
verses.textLa: Qui congregat thesauros lingua mendacii, vanus et excors est, et impingetur ad laqueos mortis.

verses.textEn: The robberies of the impious will drag them down, because they were not willing to do judgment.
verses.textLa: Rapinæ impiorum detrahent eos, quia noluerunt facere iudicium.

verses.textEn: The perverse way of a man is foreign. But whoever is pure: his work is upright.
verses.textLa: Perversa via viri, aliena est: qui autem mundus est, rectum opus eius.

verses.textEn: It is better to sit in a corner of the attic, than with a contentious woman and in a shared house.
verses.textLa: Melius est sedere in angulo domatis, quam cum muliere litigiosa, et in domo communi.

verses.textEn: The soul of the impious desires evil; he will not take pity on his neighbor.
verses.textLa: Anima impii desiderat malum, non miserebitur proximo suo.

verses.textEn: When the pestilent is punished, a little one will become wiser. And if he pursues what is wise, he will receive knowledge.
verses.textLa: Mulctato pestilente sapientior erit parvulus: et si sectetur sapientem, sumet scientiam.

verses.textEn: The just thinks carefully about the house of the impious, so that he may draw the impious away from evil.
verses.textLa: Excogitat iustus de domo impii, ut detrahat impios a malo.

verses.textEn: Whoever blocks his ears to the outcry of the poor shall also cry out himself, and he will not be heeded.
verses.textLa: Qui obturat aurem suam ad clamorem pauperis, et ipse clamabit, et non exaudietur.

verses.textEn: A surprise gift extinguishes anger. And a gift concealed in the bosom extinguishes the greatest indignation.
verses.textLa: Munus absconditum extinguit iras: et donum in sinu indignationem maximam.

verses.textEn: It is gladness for the just to do judgment; and it is dread for those who work iniquity.
verses.textLa: Gaudium iusto est facere iudicium: et pavor operantibus iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: A man who wanders astray from the way of doctrine will linger in the company of the giants.
verses.textLa: Vir, qui erraverit a via doctrinæ, in cœtu gigantum commorabitur.

verses.textEn: Whoever loves a feast will be in deprivation. Whoever loves wine and fatness will not be enriched.
verses.textLa: Qui diligit epulas, in egestate erit: qui amat vinum, et pinguia, non ditabitur.

verses.textEn: The impious is given over instead of the just, and the iniquitous is given over in place of the upright.
verses.textLa: Pro iusto datur impius: et pro rectis iniquus.

verses.textEn: It is better to live in a deserted land, than with a quarrelsome and emotional woman.
verses.textLa: Melius est habitare in terra deserta, quam cum muliere rixosa et iracunda.

verses.textEn: There is desirable treasure, as well as oil, in the habitations of the just. And the imprudent man will waste it.
verses.textLa: Thesaurus desiderabilis, et oleum in habitaculo iusti: et imprudens homo dissipabit illud.

verses.textEn: Whoever follows justice and mercy shall discover life, justice, and glory.
verses.textLa: Qui sequitur iustitiam et misericordiam, inveniet vitam, iustitiam, et gloriam.

verses.textEn: The wise has ascended the city of the strong, and he has torn down the bulwark of its confidence.
verses.textLa: Civitatem fortium ascendit sapiens, et destruxit robur fiduciæ eius.

verses.textEn: Whoever guards his mouth and his tongue guards his soul from anguish.
verses.textLa: Qui custodit os suum, et linguam suam, custodit ab angustiis animam suam.

verses.textEn: A proud and arrogant one is also called ignorant, if he, in anger, acts according to pride.
verses.textLa: Superbus et arrogans vocatur indoctus, qui in ira operatur superbiam.

verses.textEn: Desires kill the lazy, for his hands are not willing to work at all.
verses.textLa: Desideria occidunt pigrum: noluerunt enim quidquam manus eius operari:

verses.textEn: He covets and desires all day long. But whoever is just shall distribute and shall not cease.
verses.textLa: tota die concupiscit et desiderat: qui autem iustus est, tribuet, et non cessabit.

verses.textEn: The sacrifices of the impious are abominable, because they are offered out of wickedness.
verses.textLa: Hostiæ impiorum abominabiles, quia offeruntur ex scelere.

verses.textEn: A lying witness will perish. An obedient man shall speak of victory.
verses.textLa: Testis mendax peribit: vir obediens loquetur victoriam.

verses.textEn: The impious man insolently hardens his face. But whoever is upright corrects his own way.
verses.textLa: Vir impius procaciter obfirmat vultum suum: qui autem rectus est, corrigit viam suam.

verses.textEn: There is no wisdom, there is no prudence, there is no counsel, which is against the Lord.
verses.textLa: Non est sapientia, non est prudentia, non est consilium contra Dominum.

verses.textEn: The horse is prepared for the day of battle. But the Lord bestows salvation.
verses.textLa: Equus paratur ad diem belli: Dominus autem salutem tribuit.

verses.textEn: A good name is better than many riches. And good esteem is above silver and gold.
verses.textLa: Melius est nomen bonum, quam divitiæ multæ: super argentum et aurum, gratia bona.

verses.textEn: The rich and poor have met one another. The Lord is the maker of them both.
verses.textLa: Dives, et pauper obviaverunt sibi: utriusque operator est Dominus.

verses.textEn: The clever saw evil and hid himself. The innocent continued on and was afflicted with damage.
verses.textLa: Callidus vidit malum, et abscondit se: innocens pertransiit, et afflictus est damno.

verses.textEn: The end of moderation is the fear of the Lord, riches and glory and life.
verses.textLa: Finis modestiæ timor Domini, divitiæ et gloria et vita.
verses.notes: A translation of ‘modestiae’ as modesty would be too limited for this context. The verse refers to every type of self-restraint, including modesty. The word ‘finis’ has a dual meaning here: it refers to the limits of moderation as well as to its final result.

verses.textEn: Weapons and swords are on the way of the perverse. But he who guards his own soul withdraws far from them.
verses.textLa: Arma et gladii in via perversi: custos autem animæ suæ longe recedit ab eis.

verses.textEn: The proverb is: A youth is close to his way; even when he is old, he will not withdraw from it.
verses.textLa: Proverbium est: Adolescens iuxta viam suam, etiam cum senuerit, non recedet ab ea.

verses.textEn: The rich rule over the poor. And the borrower is servant to the lender.
verses.textLa: Dives pauperibus imperat: et qui accipit mutuum, servus est fœnerantis.

verses.textEn: Whoever sows iniquity will reap evils, and by the rod of his own wrath he will be consumed.
verses.textLa: Qui seminat iniquitatem, metet mala, et virga iræ suæ consummabitur.

verses.textEn: Whoever is inclined to mercy shall be blessed, for from his bread he has given to the poor. Whoever gives gifts will acquire victory and honor. But he carries away the soul of the receiver.
verses.textLa: Qui pronus est ad misericordiam, benedicetur: de panibus enim suis dedit pauperi. Victoriam et honorem acquiret qui dat munera: animam autem aufert accipientium.

verses.textEn: Cast out the one who ridicules, and conflict will go out with him, and accusations and insults will cease.
verses.textLa: Eiice derisorem, et exibit cum eo iurgium, cessabuntque causæ et contumeliæ.

verses.textEn: Whoever loves cleanness of heart, because of the grace of his lips, will have the king as his friend.
verses.textLa: Qui diligit cordis munditiam, propter gratiam labiorum suorum habebit amicum regem.

verses.textEn: The eyes of the Lord watch over knowledge. And the words of the iniquitous are supplanted.
verses.textLa: Oculi Domini custodiunt scientiam: et supplantantur verba iniqui.

verses.textEn: The lazy one says: “There is a lion outside. I might be slain in the midst of the streets.”
verses.textLa: Dicit piger: Leo est foris, in medio platearum occidendus sum.

verses.textEn: The mouth of a foreign woman is a deep pit; the Lord was angry with him who will fall into it.
verses.textLa: Fovea profunda, os alienæ: cui iratus est Dominus, incidet in eam.

verses.textEn: Foolishness has been bound to the heart of a child, and a rod of discipline shall cause it to flee.
verses.textLa: Stultitia colligata est in corde pueri, et virga disciplinæ fugabit eam.

verses.textEn: Whoever slanders the poor, so as to augment his own riches, will give it away to one who is richer, and will be in need.
verses.textLa: Qui calumniatur pauperem, ut augeat divitias suas, dabit ipse ditiori, et egebit.

verses.textEn: Incline your ear, and listen to the words of the wise. Then apply your heart to my doctrine.
verses.textLa: Inclina aurem tuam, et audi verba sapientium: appone autem cor ad doctrinam meam.

verses.textEn: It shall be beautiful to you, if you preserve it in your inner self, and it shall overflow from your lips,
verses.textLa: Quæ pulchra erit tibi, cum servaveris eam in ventre tuo, et redundabit in labiis tuis,

verses.textEn: so that your confidence may be in the Lord. Therefore, I also have revealed it to you this day.
verses.textLa: ut sit in Domino fiducia tua, unde et ostendi eam tibi hodie.

verses.textEn: Behold, I have written it for you in three ways, and with meditations and knowledge,
verses.textLa: Ecce descripsi eam tibi tripliciter, in cogitationibus et scientia:

verses.textEn: so that I might reveal to you, firmly and with words of truth, in order to respond about these things to those who sent you.
verses.textLa: ut ostenderem tibi firmitatem, et eloquia veritatis, respondere ex his illis, qui miserunt te.

verses.textEn: Do not act with violence toward the pauper because he is poor. And do not weary the needy at the gate.
verses.textLa: Non facias violentiam pauperi, quia pauper est: neque conteras egenum in porta:

verses.textEn: For the Lord will judge his case, and he will pierce those who have pierced his soul.
verses.textLa: quia iudicabit Dominus causam eius, et configet eos, qui confixerunt animam eius.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to be a friend to an angry man, and do not walk with a furious man,
verses.textLa: Noli esse amicus homini iracundo, neque ambules cum viro furioso:

verses.textEn: lest perhaps you learn his ways, and take up a stumbling block to your soul.
verses.textLa: ne forte discas semitas eius, et sumas scandalum animæ tuæ.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to be with those who certify with their hands, and who offer themselves as a guarantee against debts.
verses.textLa: Noli esse cum his, qui defigunt manus suas, et qui vades se offerunt pro debitis:

verses.textEn: For if you do not have the means to restore, what reason should there be for him to take the covering from your bed?
verses.textLa: si enim non habes unde restituas, quid causæ est ut tollat operimentum de cubili tuo?

verses.textEn: Do not cross beyond the ancient limits that your fathers have set.
verses.textLa: Ne transgrediaris terminos antiquos, quos posuerunt patres tui.

verses.textEn: Have you seen a man swift in his work? He shall stand in the sight of kings, and not before those who are disreputable.
verses.textLa: Vidisti virum velocem in opere suo? Coram regibus stabit, nec erit ante ignobiles.

verses.textEn: When you sit down to eat with a leader, pay close attention to what has been set before your face,
verses.textLa: Quando sederis ut comedas cum principe, diligenter attende quæ apposita sunt ante faciem tuam:

verses.textEn: and put a knife to your throat, if, in such a way, you could hold your soul in your own power.
verses.textLa: et statue cultrum in gutture tuo, si tamen habes in potestate animam tuam,

verses.textEn: Do not desire his foods, in which is the bread of deceit.
verses.textLa: ne desideres de cibis eius, in quo est panis mendacii.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to labor so that you may be enriched. But set limits by your prudence.
verses.textLa: Noli laborare ut diteris: sed prudentiæ tuæ pone modum.

verses.textEn: Do not raise your eyes toward wealth that you are not able to have. For they will make themselves wings, like those of an eagle, and they will fly in the sky.
verses.textLa: Ne erigas oculos tuos ad opes, quas non potes habere: quia facient sibi pennas quasi aquilæ, et volabunt in cælum.

verses.textEn: Do not eat with an envious man, and do not desire his foods.
verses.textLa: Ne comedas cum homine invido, et ne desideres cibos eius:

verses.textEn: For, like a seer and an interpreter of dreams, he presumes what he does not know. “Eat and drink,” he will say to you; and his mind is not with you.
verses.textLa: quoniam in similitudinem arioli, et coniectoris, æstimat quod ignorat. Comede et bibe, dicet tibi: et mens eius non est tecum.

verses.textEn: The foods that you had eaten, you will vomit up. And you will lose the beauty in your words.
verses.textLa: Cibos, quos comederas, evomes: et perdes pulchros sermones tuos.

verses.textEn: Do not speak into the ears of the unwise. They will despise the doctrine of your eloquence.
verses.textLa: In auribus insipientium ne loquaris: qui despicient doctrinam eloquii tui.

verses.textEn: Do not touch the boundaries of little ones, and do not enter into the field of the fatherless.
verses.textLa: Ne attingas parvulorum terminos: et agrum pupillorum ne introeas:

verses.textEn: For their close relative is strong, and he will judge their case against you.
verses.textLa: Propinquus enim illorum fortis est: et ipse iudicabit contra te causam illorum.

verses.textEn: Let your heart enter into doctrine, and let your ears enter into words of knowledge.
verses.textLa: Ingrediatur ad doctrinam cor tuum: et aures tuæ ad verba scientiæ.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to take away discipline from a child. For if you strike him with the rod, he will not die.
verses.textLa: Noli subtrahere a puero disciplinam: si enim percusseris eum virga, non morietur.

verses.textEn: You will strike him with the rod, and so shall you deliver his soul from Hell.
verses.textLa: Tu virga percuties eum: et animam eius de inferno liberabis.

verses.textEn: My son, if your soul will become wise, my heart will be glad with you.
verses.textLa: Fili mi, si sapiens fuerit animus tuus, gaudebit tecum cor meum:

verses.textEn: And my temperament will exult, when your lips will have spoken what is upright.
verses.textLa: et exultabunt renes mei, cum locuta fuerint rectum labia tua.

verses.textEn: Let not your heart compete with sinners. But be in the fear of the Lord all day long.
verses.textLa: Non æmuletur cor tuum peccatores: sed in timore Domini esto tota die:

verses.textEn: For you will have hope in the end, and your expectation will not be taken away.
verses.textLa: quia habebis spem in novissimo, et præstolatio tua non auferetur.

verses.textEn: Listen, my son, and be wise, and direct your soul along the way.
verses.textLa: Audi fili mi, et esto sapiens: et dirige in via animum tuum.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to be in the feasts of great drinkers, nor in the carousings of those who gather to feed on flesh.
verses.textLa: Noli esse in conviviis potatorum, nec in comessationibus eorum, qui carnes ad vescendum conferunt:

verses.textEn: For those who waste time drinking, and who surrender themselves to symbols, will be consumed. And those who sleep will be clothed in rags.
verses.textLa: quia vacantes potibus, et dantes symbola consumentur, et vestietur pannis dormitatio.

verses.textEn: Listen to your father, who conceived you. And do not despise your mother, when she is old.
verses.textLa: Audi patrem tuum, qui genuit te: et ne contemnas cum senuerit mater tua.

verses.textEn: Purchase truth, and do not sell wisdom, or doctrine, or understanding.
verses.textLa: Veritatem eme, et noli vendere sapientiam, et doctrinam, et intelligentiam.

verses.textEn: The father of the just exults in gladness; he who has conceived the wise will rejoice in him.
verses.textLa: Exultat gaudio pater iusti: qui sapientem genuit, lætabitur in eo.

verses.textEn: Let your father and your mother be joyful, and may she who conceived you exult.
verses.textLa: Gaudeat pater tuus, et mater tua, et exultet quæ genuit te.

verses.textEn: My son, offer me your heart, and let your eyes keep to my ways.
verses.textLa: Præbe fili mi cor tuum mihi: et oculi tui vias meas custodiant.

verses.textEn: For a loose woman is a deep pit, and a foreign woman is a constricted well.
verses.textLa: Fovea enim profunda est meretrix: et puteus angustus, aliena.

verses.textEn: She lies in wait along the way like a robber. And the incautious one whom she sees, she will put to death.
verses.textLa: Insidiatur in via quasi latro, et quos incautos viderit, interficiet.

verses.textEn: Who has woe? Whose father has woe? Who has quarrels? Who falls into pits? Who has wounds without cause? Who has watery eyes?
verses.textLa: Cui væ? cuius patri væ? cui rixæ? cui foveæ? cui sine causa vulnera? cui suffusio oculorum?

verses.textEn: Is it not those who linger over wine, and who strive to be drinking from their cups?
verses.textLa: Nonne his, qui commorantur in vino, et student calicibus epotandis?

verses.textEn: Do not gaze into the wine when it turns gold, when its color shines in the glass. It enters pleasantly,
verses.textLa: Ne intuearis vinum quando flavescit, cum splenduerit in vitro color eius: ingreditur blande,

verses.textEn: but in the end, it will bite like a snake, and it will spread poison like a king of snakes.
verses.textLa: sed in novissimo mordebit ut coluber, et sicut regulus venena diffundet.
verses.notes: The word ‘regulus’ means ‘little king’ but refers to a poisonous snake or similar creature, perhaps even a mythological one.

verses.textEn: Your eyes will see women who are outsiders, and your heart will utter perversities.
verses.textLa: Oculi tui videbunt extraneas, et cor tuum loquetur perversa.

verses.textEn: And you will be like someone sleeping in the middle of the sea, and like a pilot, fast asleep, who has lost his hold on the helm.
verses.textLa: Et eris sicut dormiens in medio mari, et quasi sopitus gubernator, amisso clavo:

verses.textEn: And you will say: “They have beaten me, but I did not feel pain. They have dragged me, and I did not realize it. When will I awaken and find more wine?”
verses.textLa: et dices: Verberaverunt me, sed non dolui: traxerunt me, et ego non sensi: quando evigilabo, et rursus vina reperiam?

verses.textEn: Do not imitate evil men, nor desire to be among them.
verses.textLa: Ne æmuleris viros malos, nec desideres esse cum eis:

verses.textEn: For their mind meditates on robberies, and their lips speak deceptions.
verses.textLa: quia rapinas meditatur mens eorum, et fraudes labia eorum loquuntur.

verses.textEn: By wisdom shall a house be built, and by prudence shall it be strengthened.
verses.textLa: Sapientia ædificabitur domus, et prudentia roborabitur.

verses.textEn: By doctrine, the storerooms shall be filled with every substance that is precious and most beautiful.
verses.textLa: In doctrina replebuntur cellaria, universa substantia pretiosa et pulcherrima.

verses.textEn: A wise man is strong, and a well-taught man is robust and valiant.
verses.textLa: Vir sapiens, fortis est: et vir doctus, robustus et validus.

verses.textEn: For war is undertaken in an orderly manner, and safety shall be where there are many counsels.
verses.textLa: Quia cum dispositione initur bellum: et erit salus ubi multa consilia sunt.

verses.textEn: Wisdom is beyond the foolish; at the gate he will not open his mouth.
verses.textLa: Excelsa stulto sapientia, in porta non aperiet os suum.

verses.textEn: Whoever intends to do evil shall be called foolish.
verses.textLa: Qui cogitat mala facere, stultus vocabitur.

verses.textEn: The intention of the foolish is sin. And the detractor is an abomination among men.
verses.textLa: Cogitatio stulti peccatum est: et abominatio hominum detractor.

verses.textEn: If you despair, being weary in the day of anguish, your strength will be diminished.
verses.textLa: Si desperaveris lassus in die angustiæ: imminuetur fortitudo tua.

verses.textEn: Rescue those who are led away to death. And do not cease from delivering those who are dragged away to a violent death.
verses.textLa: Erue eos, qui ducuntur ad mortem: et qui trahuntur ad interitum liberare ne cesses.

verses.textEn: If you would say: “I do not have sufficient strength.” He who inspects the heart, the same one understands, and nothing slips past the one who preserves your soul. And he shall repay a man according to his works.
verses.textLa: Si dixeris: Vires non suppetunt: qui inspector est cordis, ipse intelligit, et servatorem animæ tuæ nihil fallit, reddetque homini iuxta opera sua.

verses.textEn: My son, eat honey, because it is good, and the honeycomb, because it is so sweet to your throat.
verses.textLa: Comede, fili mi, mel, quia bonum est, et favum dulcissimum gutturi tuo:
verses.notes: The superlative does not always mean the one that is above all others. It often is merely a way to emphasize a particular quality, e.g. not ‘the sweetest,’ but rather ‘so sweet’ or ‘very sweet’.

verses.textEn: So, too, is the doctrine of wisdom to your soul. When you have found it, you will have hope in the end, and your hope shall not perish.
verses.textLa: Sic et doctrina sapientiæ animæ tuæ: quam cum inveneris, habebis in novissimis spem, et spes tua non peribit.

verses.textEn: Do not lie in wait, and do not seek impiety in the house of the just, nor spoil his rest.
verses.textLa: Ne insidieris, et quæras impietatem in domo iusti, neque vastes requiem eius.

verses.textEn: For the just one will fall seven times, and he shall rise again. But the impious will fall into evil.
verses.textLa: Septies enim cadet iustus, et resurget: impii autem corruent in malum.

verses.textEn: When your enemy will fall, do not be glad, and do not let your heart exult in his ruin,
verses.textLa: Cum ceciderit inimicus tuus, ne gaudeas, et in ruina eius ne exultet cor tuum:

verses.textEn: lest perhaps the Lord see, and it displease him, and he may take away his wrath from him.
verses.textLa: ne forte videat Dominus, et displiceat ei, et auferat ab eo iram suam.

verses.textEn: Do not contend with the most wicked, and do not be a rival to the impious.
verses.textLa: Ne contendas cum pessimis, nec æmuleris impios:

verses.textEn: For the evil hold no hope in the future, and the lamp of the impious will be extinguished.
verses.textLa: quoniam non habent futurorum spem mali, et lucerna impiorum extinguetur.

verses.textEn: My son, fear the Lord, as well as the king. And do not mingle with detractors.
verses.textLa: Time Dominum, fili mi, et regem: et cum detractoribus non commiscearis:

verses.textEn: For their perdition shall rise up suddenly. And who knows what ruin will be for each of them?
verses.textLa: quoniam repente consurget perditio eorum: et ruinam utriusque quis novit?

verses.textEn: Likewise, these things are for the wise. It is not good to base judgment on knowledge of character.
verses.textLa: Hæc quoque sapientibus: Cognoscere personam in iudicio non est bonum.

verses.textEn: Those who say to the impious, “You are just,” shall be cursed by the people, and the tribes shall detest them.
verses.textLa: Qui dicunt impio: Iustus es: maledicent eis populi, et detestabuntur eos tribus.

verses.textEn: Those who argue against the impious shall be praised, and a blessing shall come upon them.
verses.textLa: Qui arguunt eum, laudabuntur: et super ipsos veniet benedictio.

verses.textEn: He shall kiss the lips, who responds with upright words.
verses.textLa: Labia deosculabitur, qui recta verba respondet.

verses.textEn: Prepare your outdoor work, and diligently cultivate your field, so that afterward, you may build your house.
verses.textLa: Præpara foris opus tuum, et diligenter exerce agrum tuum: ut postea ædifices domum tuam.

verses.textEn: Do not be a witness without cause against your neighbor. And do not mislead anyone with your lips.
verses.textLa: Ne sis testis frustra contra proximum tuum: nec lactes quemquam labiis tuis.

verses.textEn: Do not say, “I will do to him as he has done to me.” I will repay each one according to his work.
verses.textLa: Ne dicas: Quomodo fecit mihi, sic faciam ei: reddam unicuique secundum opus suum.

verses.textEn: I passed by the field of a lazy man, and by the vineyard of a foolish man,
verses.textLa: Per agrum hominis pigri transivi, et per vineam viri stulti:

verses.textEn: and behold, it was entirely filled with nettles, and thorns had covered its surface, and the stonewall was destroyed.
verses.textLa: et ecce totum repleverant urticæ, et operuerant superficiem eius spinæ, et maceria lapidum destructa erat.

verses.textEn: When I had seen this, I laid it up in my heart, and by this example, I received discipline.
verses.textLa: Quod cum vidissem, posui in corde meo, et exemplo didici disciplinam.

verses.textEn: You will sleep a little,” I said. “You will slumber briefly. You will fold your hands a little, so as to rest.
verses.textLa: Parum, inquam, dormies, modicum dormitabis, pauxillum manus conseres, ut quiescas:

verses.textEn: And destitution will overtake you like a runner, and begging will overtake you like an armed man.”
verses.textLa: et veniet tibi quasi cursor egestas, et mendicitas quasi vir armatus.

verses.textEn: These, too, are parables of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, transferred.
verses.textLa: Hæ quoque parabolæ Salomonis, quas transtulerunt viri Ezechiæ regis Iuda.
verses.notes: The word ‘transtulerunt’ in this context possibly refers to translation. Perhaps they translated from Hebrew to Aramaic.

verses.textEn: It is to the glory of God to conceal a word, and it is to the glory of kings to investigate speech.
verses.textLa: Gloria Dei est celare verbum, et gloria regum investigare sermonem.

verses.textEn: Heaven above, and earth below, and the heart of kings are each unsearchable.
verses.textLa: Cælum sursum, et terra deorsum, et cor regum inscrutabile.

verses.textEn: Take away the tarnish from silver, and a most pure vessel will go forth.
verses.textLa: Aufer rubiginem de argento, et egredietur vas purissimum:

verses.textEn: Take away impiety from the face of the king, and his throne shall be made firm by justice.
verses.textLa: Aufer impietatem de vultu regis, et firmabitur iustitia thronus eius.

verses.textEn: Do not appear glorious before the king, and do not stand in the place of the great.
verses.textLa: Ne gloriosus appareas coram rege, et in loco magnorum ne steteris.

verses.textEn: For it is better that it should be said to you, “Ascend to here,” than that you should be humbled before the prince.
verses.textLa: Melius est enim ut dicatur tibi: Ascende huc; quam ut humilieris coram principe.

verses.textEn: The things that your eyes have seen, do not offer hastily in a quarrel, lest afterward you may not be able to make amends, when you have dishonored your friend.
verses.textLa: Quæ viderunt oculi tui, ne proferas in iurgio cito: ne postea emendare non possis, cum dehonestaveris amicum tuum.

verses.textEn: Argue your case with your friend, and do not reveal the secret to an outsider,
verses.textLa: Causam tuam tracta cum amico tuo, et secretum extraneo ne reveles:

verses.textEn: lest perhaps he may insult you, when he has heard it, and he might not cease to reproach you. Grace and friendship free a man; preserve these for yourself, lest you fall under reproach.
verses.textLa: ne forte insultet tibi cum audierit, et exprobrare non cesset. Gratia et amicitia liberant: quas tibi serva, ne exprobrabilis fias.

verses.textEn: Whoever speaks a word at an opportune time is like apples of gold on beds of silver.
verses.textLa: Mala aurea in lectis argenteis, qui loquitur verbum in tempore suo.

verses.textEn: Whoever reproves the wise and obedient ear is like an earring of gold with a shining pearl.
verses.textLa: Inauris aurea, et margaritum fulgens, qui arguit sapientem, et aurem obedientem.

verses.textEn: Just like the cold of snow in a time of harvest, so also is a faithful messenger to him who sent him: he causes his soul to rest.
verses.textLa: Sicut frigus nivis in die messis, ita legatus fidelis ei, qui misit eum, animam ipsius requiescere facit.
verses.notes: If it snows before the harvest, the farmer worries about the crop. But if it snows during the harvest, he rests without worry, because the crop is already mature (and will not be harmed by the cold), and the colder temperature is refreshing during his work.

verses.textEn: A man who boasts and does not fulfill his promises is like clouds and wind, when rain does not follow.
verses.textLa: Nubes, et ventus, et pluviæ non sequentes, vir gloriosus, et promissa non complens.

verses.textEn: By patience, a leader shall be appeased, and a soft tongue shall break hardness.
verses.textLa: Patientia lenietur princeps, et lingua mollis confringet duritiam.

verses.textEn: You have discovered honey; eat what is sufficient for you, lest perhaps, being filled up, you may vomit it.
verses.textLa: Mel invenisti, comede quod sufficit tibi, ne forte satiatus evomas illud.

verses.textEn: Withdraw your feet from the house of your neighbor, lest, when he has had his fill, he may hate you.
verses.textLa: Subtrahe pedem tuum de domo proximi tui, nequando satiatus oderit te.

verses.textEn: A man who speaks false testimony against his neighbor is like a dart and a sword and a sharp arrow.
verses.textLa: Iaculum, et gladius, et sagitta acuta, homo qui loquitur contra proximum suum falsum testimonium.

verses.textEn: Whoever sets his hopes on the unfaithful in a day of anguish is like a rotten tooth and weary foot,
verses.textLa: Dens putridus, et pes lassus, qui sperat super infideli in die angustiæ,

verses.textEn: and like one who loosens his garment in cold weather. Whoever sings verses to a wicked heart is like vinegar on baking soda. Just like a moth to a garment, and a worm to wood, so too does the sadness of a man do harm to the heart.
verses.textLa: et amittit pallium in die frigoris. Acetum in nitro, qui cantat carmina cordi pessimo. Sicut tinea vestimento, et vermis ligno: ita tristitia viri nocet cordi.

verses.textEn: If your enemy is hungry, feed him. If he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
verses.textLa: Si esurierit inimicus tuus, ciba illum: si sitierit, da ei aquam bibere:

verses.textEn: For you will gather hot coals upon his head, and the Lord will repay you.
verses.textLa: prunas enim congregabis super caput eius, et Dominus reddet tibi.

verses.textEn: The north wind brings forth the rain, and a sorrowful face brings forth a detracting tongue.
verses.textLa: Ventus aquilo dissipat pluvias, et facies tristis linguam detrahentem.

verses.textEn: It is better to sit in a corner of the attic, than with an argumentative woman and in a shared house.
verses.textLa: Melius est sedere in angulo domatis, quam cum muliere litigiosa, et in domo communi.

verses.textEn: Like cold water to a thirsty soul, so too are good reports from a far away land.
verses.textLa: Aqua frigida animæ sitienti, et nuncius bonus de terra longinqua.

verses.textEn: The just falling down before the impious is like a fountain stirred up by feet and like a corrupted spring.
verses.textLa: Fons turbatus pede, et vena corrupta, iustus cadens coram impio.

verses.textEn: Just as whoever eats too much honey, it is not good for him, so also whoever is an investigator of what is majestic will be overwhelmed by glory.
verses.textLa: Sicut qui mel multum comedit, non est ei bonum: sic qui scrutator est maiestatis, opprimetur a gloria.

verses.textEn: Just like a city lying in the open and without surrounding walls, so also is a man who is unable to restrain his own spirit in speaking.
verses.textLa: Sicut urbs patens et absque murorum ambitu, ita vir, qui non potest in loquendo cohibere spiritum suum.

verses.textEn: In the manner of snow in the summer, and rain at the harvest, so also is glory unfit for the foolish.
verses.textLa: Quomodo nix in æstate, et pluviæ in messe: sic indecens est stulto gloria.

verses.textEn: Like a bird flying away to another place, and like a sparrow that hurries away freely, so also a curse uttered against someone without cause will pass away.
verses.textLa: Sicut avis ad alia transvolans, et passer quo libet vadens: sic maledictum frustra prolatum in quempiam superveniet.
verses.notes: In this case, the ‘super’ in ‘superveniet’ means ‘beyond’ or ‘away,’ rather than ‘upon.’

verses.textEn: A whip is for a horse, and a muzzle is for donkey, and a rod is for the back of the imprudent.
verses.textLa: Flagellum equo, et camus asino, et virga in dorso imprudentium.

verses.textEn: Do not respond to the foolish according to his folly, lest you become like him.
verses.textLa: Ne respondeas stulto iuxta stultitiam suam, ne efficiaris ei similis.

verses.textEn: Respond to the foolish according to his folly, lest he imagine himself to be wise.
