verses.textLa: Responde stulto iuxta stultitiam suam, ne sibi sapiens esse videatur.
verses.notes: Yes, these two verses actually do tell the reader to respond and not to respond.

verses.textEn: Whoever sends words by a foolish messenger has lame feet and drinks iniquity.
verses.textLa: Claudus pedibus, et iniquitatem bibens, qui mittit verba per nuncium stultum.

verses.textEn: In the manner of a lame man who has beautiful legs to no purpose, so also is a parable unfit for the mouth of the foolish.
verses.textLa: Quomodo pulchras frustra habet claudus tibias: sic indecens est in ore stultorum parabola.

verses.textEn: Just like one who casts a stone into the pile of Mercury, so also is he who gives honor to the foolish.
verses.textLa: Sicut qui mittit lapidem in acervum Mercurii: ita qui tribuit insipienti honorem.

verses.textEn: In the manner of a thorn, if it were to spring up from the hand of a drunkard, so also is a parable in the mouth of the foolish.
verses.textLa: Quomodo si spina nascatur in manu temulenti: sic parabola in ore stultorum.
verses.notes: If a drunkard had a thorn sticking out of his hand, he would repeatedly and inadvertently harm himself with it.

verses.textEn: Judgment determines cases. And whoever imposes silence on the foolish mitigates anger.
verses.textLa: Iudicium determinat causas: et qui imponit stulto silentium, iras mitigat.

verses.textEn: Like a dog that returns to his vomit, so also is the imprudent who repeats his foolishness.
verses.textLa: Sicut canis, qui revertitur ad vomitum suum, sic imprudens, qui iterat stultitiam suam.

verses.textEn: Have you seen a man who seems wise to himself? There will be greater hope held for the unwise than for him.
verses.textLa: Vidisti hominem sapientem sibi videri? magis illo spem habebit insipiens.

verses.textEn: The lazy one says, “There is a lion along the way, and a lioness in the roads.”
verses.textLa: Dicit piger: Leo est in via, et leæna in itineribus:

verses.textEn: Just as a door turns upon its hinges, so also does the lazy one turn upon his bed.
verses.textLa: sicut ostium vertitur in cardine suo, ita piger in lectulo suo.

verses.textEn: The lazy one conceals his hand under his arms, and it is a labor for him to move it to his mouth.
verses.textLa: Abscondit piger manum sub ascella sua, et laborat si ad os suum eam converterit.

verses.textEn: The lazy one seems wiser to himself than seven men speaking judgments.
verses.textLa: Sapientior sibi piger videtur septem viris loquentibus sententias.

verses.textEn: Just like one who takes hold of a dog by the ears, so also is he who crosses impatiently and meddles in the quarrels of another.
verses.textLa: Sicut qui apprehendit auribus canem, sic qui transit impatiens, et commiscetur rixæ alterius.

verses.textEn: Just as he is guilty who let loose the arrows and the lances unto death,
verses.textLa: Sicut noxius est qui mittit sagittas, et lanceas in mortem:

verses.textEn: so also is the man who harms his friend by deceitfulness. And when he has been apprehended, he says, “I did it jokingly.”
verses.textLa: ita vir, fraudulenter nocet amico suo: et cum fuerit deprehensus, dicit: Ludens feci.

verses.textEn: When the wood fails, the fire will be extinguished. And when the gossiper is taken away, conflicts will be quelled.
verses.textLa: Cum defecerint ligna, extinguetur ignis: et susurrone subtracto, iurgia conquiescent.

verses.textEn: Just as charcoals are to burning coals, and wood is to fire, so also is an angry man who stirs up quarrels.
verses.textLa: Sicut carbones ad prunas, et ligna ad ignem, sic homo iracundus suscitat rixas.

verses.textEn: The words of a whisperer seem simple, but they penetrate to the innermost parts of the self.
verses.textLa: Verba susurronis quasi simplicia, et ipsa perveniunt ad intima ventris.

verses.textEn: In the same manner as an earthen vessel, if it were adorned with impure silver, conceited lips are allied with a wicked heart.
verses.textLa: Quomodo si argento sordido ornare velis vas fictile, sic labia tumentia cum pessimo corde sociata.
verses.notes: Even though ‘pessimo’ is superlative, the translation does not need to use the grammatical superlative because ‘wicked’ includes a superlative meaning, i.e. most bad or very bad.

verses.textEn: An enemy is known by his lips, though it is from his heart that he draws out deceit.
verses.textLa: Labiis suis intelligitur inimicus, cum in corde tractaverit dolos.

verses.textEn: When he will have lowered his voice, do not believe him, for there are seven vices in his heart.
verses.textLa: Quando submiserit vocem suam, ne credideris ei: quoniam septem nequitiæ sunt in corde illius.

verses.textEn: Whoever covers hatred with deceit, his malice shall be revealed in the assembly.
verses.textLa: Qui operit odium fraudulenter, revelabitur malitia eius in consilio.

verses.textEn: Whoever digs a pit will fall into it. And whoever rolls a stone, it will roll back to him.
verses.textLa: Qui fodit foveam, incidet in eam: et qui volvit lapidem, revertetur ad eum.

verses.textEn: A false tongue does not love truth. And a slippery mouth works ruin.
verses.textLa: Lingua fallax non amat veritatem: et os lubricum operatur ruinas.

verses.textEn: Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what the future day may bring.
verses.textLa: Ne glorieris in crastinum, ignorans quid superventura pariat dies.

verses.textEn: Let another praise you, and not your own mouth: an outsider, and not your own lips.
verses.textLa: Laudet te alienus, et non os tuum: extraneus, et non labia tua.

verses.textEn: A stone is weighty, and sand is burdensome; but the wrath of the foolish is heavier than both.
verses.textLa: Grave est saxum, et onerosa arena: sed ira stulti utroque gravior.

verses.textEn: Anger holds no mercy, nor does fury when it erupts. And who can bear the assault of one who has been provoked?
verses.textLa: Ira non habet misericordiam, nec erumpens furor: et impetum concitati ferre quis poterit?

verses.textEn: An open rebuke is better than hidden love.
verses.textLa: Melior est manifesta correptio, quam amor absconditus.

verses.textEn: The wounds of a loved one are better than the deceitful kisses of a hateful one.
verses.textLa: Meliora sunt vulnera diligentis, quam fraudulenta oscula odientis.

verses.textEn: A sated soul will trample the honeycomb. And a hungry soul will accept even bitter in place of sweet.
verses.textLa: Anima saturata calcabit favum: et anima esuriens etiam amarum pro dulci sumet.

verses.textEn: Just like a bird migrating from her nest, so also is a man who abandons his place.
verses.textLa: Sicut avis transmigrans de nido suo, sic vir qui derelinquit locum suum.

verses.textEn: Ointment and various perfumes delight the heart. And the good advice of a friend is sweet to the soul.
verses.textLa: Unguento et variis odoribus delectatur cor: et bonis amici consiliis anima dulcoratur.

verses.textEn: Do not dismiss your friend or your father’s friend. And do not enter your brother’s house in the day of your affliction. A close neighbor is better than a distant brother.
verses.textLa: Amicum tuum, et amicum patris tui ne dimiseris: et domum fratris tui ne ingrediaris in die afflictionis tuæ. Melior est vicinus iuxta, quam frater procul.

verses.textEn: My son, study wisdom, and rejoice my heart, so that you may be able to respond to the one who reproaches.
verses.textLa: Stude sapientiæ fili mi, et lætifica cor meum, ut possis exprobranti respondere sermonem.

verses.textEn: The discerning man, seeing evil, hides himself. The little ones, continuing on, sustain losses.
verses.textLa: Astutus videns malum, absconditus est: parvuli transeuntes sustinuerunt dispendia.

verses.textEn: Take away the garment of him who has vouched for an outsider. And take a pledge from him on behalf of foreigners.
verses.textLa: Tolle vestimentum eius, qui spopondit pro extraneo: et pro alienis, aufer ei pignus.

verses.textEn: Whoever blesses his neighbor with a grand voice, rising in the night, shall be like one who curses.
verses.textLa: Qui benedicit proximo suo voce grandi, de nocte consurgens maledicenti similis erit.

verses.textEn: A roof leaking on a cold day, and an argumentative woman, are comparable.
verses.textLa: Tecta perstillantia in die frigoris, et litigiosa mulier comparantur:

verses.textEn: He who would restrain her, he is like one who would grasp the wind, or who would gather together oil with his right hand.
verses.textLa: qui retinet eam, quasi qui ventum teneat, et oleum dexteræ suæ vocabit.

verses.textEn: Iron sharpens iron, and a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.
verses.textLa: Ferrum ferro exacuitur, et homo exacuit faciem amici sui.

verses.textEn: Whoever maintains the fig tree shall eat its fruit. And whoever is the keeper of his master shall be glorified.
verses.textLa: Qui servat ficum, comedet fructus eius: et qui custos est domini sui, glorificabitur.

verses.textEn: In the manner of faces looking into shining water, so are the hearts of men made manifest to the prudent.
verses.textLa: Quomodo in aquis resplendent vultus prospicientium, sic corda hominum manifesta sunt prudentibus.

verses.textEn: Hell and perdition are never filled; similarly the eyes of men are insatiable.
verses.textLa: Infernus et perditio numquam implentur: similiter et oculi hominum insatiabiles:

verses.textEn: In the manner of silver being tested in the refinery, and gold in the furnace, so also is a man tested by the mouth of one who praises. The heart of the iniquitous inquires after evils, but the heart of the righteous inquires after knowledge.
verses.textLa: Quomodo probatur in conflatorio argentum, et in fornace aurum: sic probatur homo ore laudantis. Cor iniqui inquirit mala, cor autem rectum inquirit scientiam.

verses.textEn: Even if you were to crush the foolish with a mortar, as when a pestle strikes over pearled barley, his foolishness would not be taken from him.
verses.textLa: Si contuderis stultum in pila quasi ptisanas feriente desuper pilo, non auferetur ab eo stultitia eius.

verses.textEn: Be diligent to know the countenance of your cattle, and consider your own flocks,
verses.textLa: Diligenter agnosce vultum pecoris tui, tuosque greges considera:

verses.textEn: for you will not always hold this power. But a crown shall be awarded from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: Non enim habebis iugiter potestatem: sed corona tribuetur in generationem et generationem.

verses.textEn: The meadows are open, and the green plants have appeared, and the hay has been collected from the mountains.
verses.textLa: Aperta sunt prata, et apparuerunt herbæ virentes, et collecta sunt fœna de montibus.

verses.textEn: Lambs are for your clothing, and goats are for the price of a field.
verses.textLa: Agni ad vestimentum tuum: et hœdi, ad agri pretium.

verses.textEn: Let the milk of goats be sufficient for your food, and for the necessities of your household, and for the provisions of your handmaids.
verses.textLa: Sufficiat tibi lac caprarum in cibos tuos, et in necessaria domus tuæ: et ad victum ancillis tuis.

verses.textEn: The impious flees, though no one pursues. But the just, like a confident lion, shall be without dread.
verses.textLa: Fugit impius, nemine persequente: iustus autem quasi leo confidens, absque terrore erit.

verses.textEn: Because of the sins of the land, it has many princes. And because of the wisdom of a man, and the knowledge of those things that are said, the life of the leader shall be prolonged.
verses.textLa: Propter peccata terræ multi principes eius: et propter hominis sapientiam, et horum scientiam quæ dicuntur, vita ducis longior erit.

verses.textEn: A poor man slandering the poor is like a violent rainstorm in advance of a famine.
verses.textLa: Vir pauper calumnians pauperes, similis est imbri vehementi, in quo paratur fames.

verses.textEn: Those who abandon the law praise the impious. Those who guard it are inflamed against him.
verses.textLa: Qui derelinquunt legem, laudant impium: qui custodiunt, succenduntur contra eum.

verses.textEn: Evil men do not intend judgment. But those who inquire after the Lord turn their souls toward all things.
verses.textLa: Viri mali non cogitant iudicium: qui autem inquirunt Dominum, animadvertunt omnia.

verses.textEn: Better is the pauper walking in his simplicity, than the rich walking in ways of depravity.
verses.textLa: Melior est pauper ambulans in simplicitate sua, quam dives in pravis itineribus.

verses.textEn: Whoever keeps the law is a wise son. But whoever feeds gluttons brings shame to his father.
verses.textLa: Qui custodit legem, filius sapiens est: qui autem comessatores pascit, confundit patrem suum.

verses.textEn: Whoever piles up riches by usury and profit gathers them for him who will give freely to the poor.
verses.textLa: Qui coacervat divitias usuris et fœnore, liberali in pauperes congregat eas.

verses.textEn: Whoever turns away his ears from listening to the law: his prayer will be detestable.
verses.textLa: Qui declinat aures suas ne audiat legem, oratio eius erit execrabilis.

verses.textEn: Whoever deceives the just in a malicious way will fall into his own perdition. And the simple shall possess his goods.
verses.textLa: Qui decipit iustos in via mala, in interitu suo corruet: et simplices possidebunt bona eius.

verses.textEn: The rich one seems wise to himself. But the poor one, being prudent, shall evaluate him.
verses.textLa: Sapiens sibi videtur vir dives: pauper autem prudens scrutabitur eum.

verses.textEn: In the exultation of the just, there is great glory. When the impious reign, men are brought to ruin.
verses.textLa: In exultatione iustorum multa gloria est: regnantibus impiis ruinæ hominum.

verses.textEn: Whoever hides his crimes will not be guided. But whoever will have confessed and abandoned them shall overtake mercy.
verses.textLa: Qui abscondit scelera sua, non dirigetur: qui autem confessus fuerit, et reliquerit ea, misericordiam consequetur.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man who is ever fearful. Yet truly, whoever is hardened in mind will fall into evil.
verses.textLa: Beatus homo, qui semper est pavidus: qui vero mentis est duræ, corruet in malum.

verses.textEn: An impious leader over a poor people is like a roaring lion and a hungry bear.
verses.textLa: Leo rugiens, et ursus esuriens, princeps impius super populum pauperem.

verses.textEn: A leader destitute of prudence will oppress many through false accusations. But whoever hates avarice shall prolong his days.
verses.textLa: Dux indigens prudentia, multos opprimet per calumniam: qui autem odit avaritiam, longi fient dies eius.

verses.textEn: A man who slanders the blood of a life, even if he flees to the pit, no one will tolerate him.
verses.textLa: Hominem, qui calumniatur animæ sanguinem, si usque ad lacum fugerit, nemo sustinet.

verses.textEn: Whoever walks simply shall be saved. Whoever is perverse in his steps will fall all at once.
verses.textLa: Qui ambulat simpliciter, salvus erit: qui perversis graditur viis, concidet semel.

verses.textEn: Whoever works his land shall be satisfied with bread. But whoever pursues leisure will be filled with need.
verses.textLa: Qui operatur terram suam, satiabitur panibus: qui autem sectatur otium, replebitur egestate.

verses.textEn: A faithful man shall be greatly praised. But whoever rushes to become rich will not be innocent.
verses.textLa: Vir fidelis multum laudabitur: qui autem festinat ditari, non erit innocens.

verses.textEn: Whoever shows favoritism in judgment does not do well; even if it is for a morsel of bread, he forsakes the truth.
verses.textLa: Qui cognoscit in iudicio faciem, non bene facit: iste et pro buccella panis deserit veritatem.

verses.textEn: A man who hurries to become rich, and who envies others, does not know that destitution will overwhelm him.
verses.textLa: Vir, qui festinat ditari, et aliis invidet, ignorat quod egestas superveniet ei.

verses.textEn: Whoever corrects a man, afterward he shall find favor with him, more so than he who deceives him with a flattering tongue.
verses.textLa: Qui corripit hominem, gratiam postea inveniet apud eum magis quam ille, qui per linguæ blandimenta decipit.

verses.textEn: Whoever takes away anything from his father or mother, and who says, “This is not a sin,” is the associate of a murderer.
verses.textLa: Qui subtrahit aliquid a patre suo, et a matre: et dicit hoc non esse peccatum, particeps homicidæ est.

verses.textEn: Whoever boasts and enlarges himself stirs up conflicts. Yet truly, whoever trusts in the Lord will be healed.
verses.textLa: Qui se iactat, et dilatat, iurgia concitat: qui vero sperat in Domino, sanabitur.

verses.textEn: Whoever trusts in his own heart is a fool. But whoever treads wisely, the same shall be saved.
verses.textLa: Qui confidit in corde suo, stultus est: qui autem graditur sapienter, ipse salvabitur.

verses.textEn: Whoever gives to the poor shall not be in need. Whoever despises his petition will suffer scarcity.
verses.textLa: Qui dat pauperi, non indigebit: qui despicit deprecantem, sustinebit penuriam.

verses.textEn: When the impious rise up, men will hide themselves. When they perish, the just shall be multiplied.
verses.textLa: Cum surrexerint impii, abscondentur homines: cum illi perierint, multiplicabuntur iusti.

verses.textEn: The man who, with a stiff neck, treats the one who corrects him with contempt will be suddenly overwhelmed to his own destruction, and reason shall not follow him.
verses.textLa: Viro, qui corripientem dura cervice contemnit, repentinus ei superveniet interitus: et eum sanitas non sequetur.

verses.textEn: When just men are multiplied, the common people shall rejoice. When the impious take up the leadership, the people shall mourn.
verses.textLa: In multiplicatione iustorum lætabitur vulgus: cum impii sumpserint principatum, gemet populus.

verses.textEn: The man who loves wisdom rejoices his father. But whoever nurtures promiscuous women will lose his substance.
verses.textLa: Vir, qui amat sapientiam, lætificat patrem suum: qui autem nutrit scorta, perdet substantiam.

verses.textEn: A just king guides the land. A man of avarice will destroy it.
verses.textLa: Rex iustus erigit terram, vir avarus destruet eam.

verses.textEn: A man who speaks to his friend with flattering and feigned words spreads a net for his own feet.
verses.textLa: Homo, qui blandis, fictisque sermonibus loquitur amico suo, rete expandit gressibus eius.

verses.textEn: A snare will entangle the iniquitous when he sins. And the just shall praise and be glad.
verses.textLa: Peccantem virum iniquum involvet laqueus: et iustus laudabit atque gaudebit.

verses.textEn: The just knows the case of the poor. The impious is ignorant of knowledge.
verses.textLa: Novit iustus causam pauperum: impius ignorat scientiam.

verses.textEn: Pestilent men squander a city. Yet truly, the wise avert fury.
verses.textLa: Homines pestilentes dissipant civitatem: sapientes vero avertunt furorem.

verses.textEn: A wise man, if he were to contend with the foolish, whether in anger or in laughter, would find no rest.
verses.textLa: Vir sapiens, si cum stulto contenderit, sive irascatur, sive rideat, non inveniet requiem.

verses.textEn: Bloodthirsty men hate the simple one; but the just seek out his soul.
verses.textLa: Viri sanguinum oderunt simplicem: iusti autem quærunt animam eius.

verses.textEn: A foolish one offers everything on his mind. A wise one reserves and defers until later.
verses.textLa: Totum spiritum suum profert stultus: sapiens differt, et reservat in posterum.

verses.textEn: A leader who freely listens to lying words has only impious servants.
verses.textLa: Princeps, qui libenter audit verba mendacii, omnes ministros habet impios.

verses.textEn: The pauper and the creditor have met one another. The Lord is the illuminator of them both.
verses.textLa: Pauper, et creditor obviaverunt sibi: utriusque illuminator est Dominus.

verses.textEn: The king who judges the poor in truth, his throne shall be secured in eternity.
verses.textLa: Rex, qui iudicat in veritate pauperes, thronus eius in æternum firmabitur.

verses.textEn: The rod and its correction distribute wisdom. But the child who is left to his own will, brings shame to his mother.
verses.textLa: Virga atque correptio tribuit sapientiam: puer autem, qui dimittitur voluntati suæ, confundit matrem suam.

verses.textEn: When the impious are multiplied, crimes will be multiplied. But the just shall see their ruin.
verses.textLa: In multiplicatione impiorum multiplicabuntur scelera: et iusti ruinas eorum videbunt.

verses.textEn: Teach your son, and he will refresh you, and he will give delight to your soul.
verses.textLa: Erudi filium tuum, et refrigerabit te, et dabit delicias animæ tuæ.

verses.textEn: When prophecy fails, the people will be scattered. Yet truly, whoever guards the law is blessed.
verses.textLa: Cum prophetia defecerit, dissipabitur populus: qui vero custodit legem, beatus est.

verses.textEn: A servant cannot be taught by words, because he understands what you say, but he disdains to respond.
verses.textLa: Servus verbis non potest erudiri: quia quod dicis intelligit, et respondere contemnit.

verses.textEn: Have you seen a man rushing to speak? Foolishness has more hope than his correction.
verses.textLa: Vidisti hominem velocem ad loquendum? stultitia magis speranda est, quam illius correptio.

verses.textEn: Whoever nurtures his servant delicately from childhood, afterwards will find him defiant.
verses.textLa: Qui delicate a pueritia nutrit servum suum, postea sentiet eum contumacem.

verses.textEn: A short-tempered man provokes quarrels. And whoever is easily angered is more likely to sin.
verses.textLa: Vir iracundus provocat rixas: et qui ad indignandum facilis est, erit ad peccandum proclivior.

verses.textEn: Humiliation follows the arrogant. And glory shall uphold the humble in spirit.
verses.textLa: Superbum sequitur humilitas: et humilem spiritu suscipiet gloria.

verses.textEn: Whoever participates with a thief hates his own soul; for he listens to his oath and does not denounce him.
verses.textLa: Qui cum fure participat, odit animam suam: adiurantem audit, et non indicat.

verses.textEn: Whoever fears man will quickly fall. Whoever hopes in the Lord shall be lifted up.
verses.textLa: Qui timet hominem, cito corruet: qui sperat in Domino, sublevabitur.

verses.textEn: Many demand the face of the leader. But the judgment of each one proceeds from the Lord.
verses.textLa: Multi requirunt faciem principis: et iudicium a Domino egreditur singulorum.

verses.textEn: The just abhor an impious man. And the impious abhor those who are on the right way. By keeping the word, the son shall be free from perdition.
verses.textLa: Abominantur iusti virum impium: et abominantur impii eos, qui in recta sunt via. Verbum custodiens filius, extra perditionem erit.

verses.textEn: The words of the Gatherer, the son of the Vomiter. The vision that the man spoke. God is with him, and he, being strengthened by God and abiding with him, said:
verses.textLa: Verba Congregantis filii Vomentis. Visio, quam locutus est vir, cum quo est Deus, et qui Deo secum morante confortatus, ait:
verses.notes: Or, ‘The words of the Gatherer, the son of the Vomiter.’

verses.textEn: “I am the most foolish among men, and the wisdom of men is not with me.
verses.textLa: Stultissimus sum virorum, et sapientia hominum non est mecum.

verses.textEn: I have not learned wisdom, and I have not known the knowledge of sanctity.
verses.textLa: Non didici sapientiam, et non novi scientiam sanctorum.

verses.textEn: Who has ascended to heaven and also descended? Who has grasped the wind in his hands? Who has tied the waters together, as with a garment? Who has raised all the limits of the earth? What is his name, and what is the name of his son, if you know?
verses.textLa: Quis ascendit in cælum atque descendit? quis continuit spiritum in manibus suis? quis colligavit aquas quasi in vestimento? quis suscitavit omnes terminos terræ? quod nomen est eius, et quod nomen filii eius, si nosti?

verses.textEn: Every word of God is fire-tested. He is a bronze shield to those who hope in him.
verses.textLa: Omnis sermo Dei ignitus, clypeus est sperantibus in se:

verses.textEn: Do not add anything to his words, lest you be reproved and be discovered to be a liar.
verses.textLa: ne addas quidquam verbis illius, et arguaris inveniarisque mendax.

verses.textEn: Two things I have asked of you; do not deny them to me before I die.
verses.textLa: Duo rogavi te, ne deneges mihi antequam moriar.

verses.textEn: Remove, far from me, vanity and lying words. Give me neither begging, nor wealth. Apportion to me only the necessities of my life,
verses.textLa: Vanitatem, et verba mendacia longe fac a me. Mendicitatem, et divitias ne dederis mihi: tribue tantum victui meo necessaria:

verses.textEn: lest perhaps, being filled, I might be enticed into denial, and say: ‘Who is the Lord?’ Or, being compelled by destitution, I might steal, and then perjure myself in the name of my God.
verses.textLa: ne forte satiatus illiciar ad negandum, et dicam: Quis est Dominus? aut egestate compulsus furer, et periurem nomen Dei mei.

verses.textEn: Do not accuse a servant to his lord, lest he curse you, and you fall.
verses.textLa: Ne accuses servum ad dominum suum, ne forte maledicat tibi, et corruas.

verses.textEn: There is a generation which curses their father, and which does not bless their mother.
verses.textLa: Generatio, quæ patri suo maledicit, et quæ matri suæ non benedicit.

verses.textEn: There is a generation which seems pure to themselves, and yet they are not even washed from their filthiness.
verses.textLa: Generatio, quæ sibi munda videtur, et tamen non est lota a sordibus suis.

verses.textEn: There is a generation, whose eyes have been elevated, and their eyelids are lifted on high.
verses.textLa: Generatio, cuius excelsi sunt oculi, et palpebræ eius in alta surrectæ.

verses.textEn: There is a generation which has swords in place of teeth, and which commands their molars to devour the indigent from the earth and the poor from among men.
verses.textLa: Generatio, quæ pro dentibus gladios habet, et commandit molaribus suis, ut comedat inopes de terra, et pauperes ex hominibus.

verses.textEn: The leech has two daughters, who say, ‘Bring, bring.’ Three things are insatiable, and a fourth never says ‘Enough’:
verses.textLa: Sanguisugæ duæ sunt filiæ, dicentes: Affer, Affer. Tria sunt insaturabilia, et quartum, quod numquam dicit: Sufficit.

verses.textEn: Hell, and the mouth of the womb, and a land that is not filled with water. And truly, fire never says, ‘Enough.’
verses.textLa: Infernus, et os vulvæ, et terra, quæ non satiatur aqua: ignis vero numquam dicit: Sufficit.

verses.textEn: The eye of one who mocks his father and who despises the childbearing of his mother, let the ravens of the torrent tear it out, and let the sons of the eagles consume it.
verses.textLa: Oculum, qui subsannat patrem, et qui despicit partum matris suæ, effodiant eum corvi de torrentibus, et comedant eum filii aquilæ.

verses.textEn: Three things are difficult for me, and about a fourth, I am nearly ignorant:
verses.textLa: Tria sunt difficilia mihi, et quartum penitus ignoro:

verses.textEn: the way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a serpent on a rock, the way of a ship in the middle of the sea, and the way of a man in adolescence.
verses.textLa: Viam aquilæ in cælo, viam colubri super petram, viam navis in medio mari, et viam viri in adolescentia.

verses.textEn: Such is the way also of an adulterous woman, who eats, and wiping her mouth, says: “I have done no evil.”
verses.textLa: Talis est et via mulieris adulteræ, quæ comedit, et tergens os suum dicit: Non sum operata malum.

verses.textEn: By three things, the earth is moved, and a fourth it is not able to sustain:
verses.textLa: Per tria movetur terra, et quartum non potest sustinere:

verses.textEn: by a slave when he reigns, by the foolish when he has been filled with food,
verses.textLa: Per servum cum regnaverit: per stultum cum saturatus fuerit cibo:

verses.textEn: by a hateful woman when she has been taken in matrimony, and by a handmaid when she has been heir to her mistress.
verses.textLa: per odiosam mulierem cum in matrimonio fuerit assumpta: et per ancillam cum fuerit heres dominæ suæ.

verses.textEn: Four things are least upon the earth, and they are wiser than the wise:
verses.textLa: Quatuor sunt minima terræ, et ipsa sunt sapientiora sapientibus.

verses.textEn: the ants, an infirm people who provide food for themselves at the harvest,
verses.textLa: Formicæ, populus infirmus, qui præparat in messe cibum sibi:

verses.textEn: the rabbit, a sickened people who make their bed upon the rock.
verses.textLa: lepusculus, plebs invalida, qui collocat in petra cubile suum:

verses.textEn: The locust has no king, but they all depart by their troops.
verses.textLa: regem locusta non habet, et egreditur universa per turmas suas:

verses.textEn: The lizard supports itself on hands and dwells in the buildings of kings.
verses.textLa: stellio manibus nititur, et moratur in ædibus regis.

verses.textEn: There are three things that advance well, and a fourth that marches happily on:
verses.textLa: Tria sunt, quæ bene gradiuntur, et quartum, quod incedit feliciter:

verses.textEn: a lion, the strongest of beasts, who fears nothing that he meets,
verses.textLa: Leo fortissimus bestiarum, ad nullius pavebit occursum:

verses.textEn: a rooster prepared at the loins, likewise a ram, and a king, whom none can resist.
verses.textLa: gallus succinctus lumbos: et aries: nec est rex, qui resistat ei.

verses.textEn: There is one who has appeared foolish, after he was lifted up on high; for if he had understood, he would have placed his hand over his mouth.
verses.textLa: Est qui stultus apparuit postquam elevatus est in sublime: si enim intellexisset, ori suo imposuisset manum.

verses.textEn: But whoever strongly squeezes the udder to bring out the milk, presses out butter. And whoever violently blows his nose, brings out blood. And whoever provokes wrath, brings forth discord.”
verses.textLa: Qui autem fortiter premit ubera ad eliciendum lac, exprimit butyrum: et qui vehementer emungit, elicit sanguinem: et qui provocat iras, producit discordias.
verses.notes: Now pressing out milk strongly does not literally produce butter; but this is a type of figure of speech where the literal meaning is not true and is not what is being asserted as true. It is the figurative meaning that is being asserted as true.

verses.textEn: The words of king Lamuel. The vision by which his mother instructed him:
verses.textLa: Verba Lamuelis regis. Visio, qua erudivit eum mater sua.

verses.textEn: “What, O my beloved? What, O beloved of my womb? What, O beloved of my vows?
verses.textLa: Quid dilecte mi, quid dilecte uteri mei, quid dilecte votorum meorum?

verses.textEn: Do not give your substance to women, or your riches to overthrow kings.
verses.textLa: Ne dederis mulieribus substantiam tuam, et divitias tuas ad delendos reges.

verses.textEn: Not to kings, O Lamuel, not to kings give wine. For there are no secrets where drunkenness reigns.
verses.textLa: Noli regibus, o Lamuel, noli regibus dare vinum: quia nullum secretum est ubi regnat ebrietas.

verses.textEn: And perhaps they may drink and forget judgments, and alter the case of the sons of the poor.
verses.textLa: Et ne forte bibant, et obliviscantur iudiciorum, et mutent causam filiorum pauperis.

verses.textEn: Give strong drink to the grieving, and wine to those who are bitter in soul.
verses.textLa: Date siceram mœrentibus, et vinum his, qui amaro sunt animo:

verses.textEn: Let them drink, and forget their needs, and remember their sorrow no more.
verses.textLa: bibant, et obliviscantur egestatis suæ, et doloris sui non recordentur amplius.

verses.textEn: Open your mouth for the mute and for all the cases of the sons who are passing through.
verses.textLa: Aperi os tuum muto, et causis omnium filiorum qui pertranseunt:

verses.textEn: Open your mouth, declare what is just, and do justice to the indigent and the poor.
verses.textLa: aperi os tuum, decerne quod iustum est, et iudica inopem et pauperem.

verses.textEn: Who shall find a strong woman? Far away, and from the furthest parts, is her price.
verses.textLa: Mulierem fortem quis inveniet? procul, et de ultimis finibus pretium eius.

verses.textEn: The heart of her husband confides in her, and he will not be deprived of spoils.
verses.textLa: Confidit in ea cor viri sui, et spoliis non indigebit.

verses.textEn: She will repay him with good, and not evil, all the days of her life.
verses.textLa: Reddet ei bonum, et non malum, omnibus diebus vitæ suæ.

verses.textEn: She has sought wool and flax, and she has worked these by the counsel of her hands.
verses.textLa: Quæsivit lanam et linum, et operata est consilia manuum suarum.

verses.textEn: She has become like a merchant’s ship, bringing her bread from far away.
verses.textLa: Facta est quasi navis institoris, de longe portans panem suum.

verses.textEn: And she has risen in the night, and given a prey to her household, and provisions to her maids.
verses.textLa: Et de nocte surrexit, deditque prædam domesticis suis, et cibaria ancillis suis.

verses.textEn: She has considered a field and bought it. From the fruit of her own hands, she has planted a vineyard.
verses.textLa: Consideravit agrum, et emit eum: de fructu manuum suarum plantavit vineam.

verses.textEn: She has wrapped her waist with fortitude, and she has strengthened her arm.
verses.textLa: Accinxit fortitudine lumbos suos, et roboravit brachium suum.

verses.textEn: She has tasted and seen that her tasks are good; her lamp shall not be extinguished at night.
verses.textLa: Gustavit, et vidit quia bona est negotiatio eius: non extinguetur in nocte lucerna eius.

verses.textEn: She has put her hand to strong things, and her fingers have taken hold of the spindle.
verses.textLa: Manum suam misit ad fortia, et digiti eius apprehenderunt fusum.

verses.textEn: She has opened her hand to the needy, and she has extended her hands to the poor.
verses.textLa: Manum suam aperuit inopi, et palmas suas extendit ad pauperem.

verses.textEn: She shall not fear, in the cold of snow, for her household. For all those of her household have been clothed two-fold.
verses.textLa: Non timebit domui suæ a frigoribus nivis: omnes enim domestici eius vestiti sunt duplicibus.

verses.textEn: She has made embroidered clothing for herself. Fine linen and purple is her garment.
verses.textLa: Stragulatam vestem fecit sibi: byssus, et purpura indumentum eius.

verses.textEn: Her husband is noble at the gates, when he sits among the senators of the land.
verses.textLa: Nobilis in portis vir eius, quando sederit cum senatoribus terræ.

verses.textEn: She has made finely woven cloth and sold it, and she has delivered a waistband to the Canaanite.
verses.textLa: Sindonem fecit, et vendidit, et cingulum tradidit Chananæo.
verses.notes: The word ‘cingulum’ refers to something that encircles or wraps; in this context, it is made of cloth. It could conceivably be anything from a headband to an undergarment.

verses.textEn: Strength and elegance are her clothing, and she will laugh in the final days.
verses.textLa: Fortitudo et decor indumentum eius, et ridebit in die novissimo.

verses.textEn: She has opened her mouth to wisdom, and the law of clemency is on her tongue.
verses.textLa: Os suum aperuit sapientiæ, et lex clementiæ in lingua eius.

verses.textEn: She has considered the paths of her household, and she has not eaten her bread in idleness.
verses.textLa: Consideravit semitas domus suæ, et panem otiosa non comedit.

verses.textEn: Her sons rose up and predicted great happiness; her husband rose up and praised her.
verses.textLa: Surrexerunt filii eius, et beatissimam prædicaverunt: vir eius, et laudavit eam.
verses.notes: Or, ‘Her sons rose up and proclaimed her most blessed;”

verses.textEn: Many daughters have gathered together riches; you have surpassed them all.
verses.textLa: Multæ filiæ congregaverunt divitias: tu supergressa es universas.

verses.textEn: Charm is false, and beauty is vain. The woman who fears the Lord, the same shall be praised.
verses.textLa: Fallax gratia, et vana est pulchritudo: mulier timens Dominum ipsa laudabitur.

verses.textEn: Give to her from the fruit of her own hands. And let her works praise her at the gates.
verses.textLa: Date ei de fructu manuum suarum: et laudent eam in portis opera eius.
